question.title: Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
question.body:
Resolves **Yes** if one of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:

 - Donald Trump
 - Donald Trump Jr.
 - Eric Trump
 - Ivanka Trump
 - Tiffany Trump
 - Melania Trump
 - Barron Trump

metadata.background_info:
Donald John Trump is the 45th and current president of the United States. Before entering politics, he was a businessman and television personality. Trump won a surprise victory in the [2016 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election), and sought re-election in the [2020 presidential election.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election)

The [Trump family](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_of_Donald_Trump) has a net worth reported to be in the single-digit billions, and is now one of the most prominent families in Republican politics. Trump has several adult children, and there is speculation that a Trump political dynasty may emerge in the coming years, with both [Donald Trump Jr. and Ivanka Trump suggested as possible contenders for the presidency.](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/jan/04/donald-trump-jr-ivanka-trump-2024-presidential-election-poll)

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Donald Trump is the leading candidate in the Republican primary race for the 2024 US Presidential election. He has consistently maintained a significant lead in national polls over other Republican contenders such as Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and Mike Pence. Despite facing multiple legal challenges and indictments, his base of support within the Republican Party remains strong. No other members of the Trump family listed (Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, Barron Trump) have declared their candidacy or shown significant interest in running. Considering these factors, it is highly likely that Donald Trump will secure the Republican nomination.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Donald Trump)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.  All other candidates will resolve as **No**.  This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, Donald Trump remains the leading candidate for the Republican nomination for the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election. Polls consistently show him with a significant lead over other Republican contenders such as Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and Mike Pence. His strong support base within the party has remained resilient despite multiple legal challenges and indictments he is currently facing. In some cases, these legal issues have even galvanized his supporters, reinforcing their commitment to his candidacy.

The Republican National Convention nominates the candidate who secures the majority of delegates through primary elections and caucuses. Given Trump's prominent position in the polls and his widespread name recognition, he is well-positioned to accumulate the necessary delegates. Additionally, his fundraising efforts have been robust, allowing for a sustained campaign.

However, uncertainties remain. Legal proceedings could potentially impact his eligibility or sway public opinion. There's also the possibility of a significant shift within the Republican Party's leadership or voter base that could elevate another candidate. Health issues or other unforeseen events could also alter the current trajectory.

Considering these factors—the strong current support for Trump, the structural advantages he holds, and the potential but less likely risks—I estimate a high probability that Donald Trump will be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 election.

question.title: Will Scotland hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if there is a referendum held in Scotland regarding Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom, and this referendum is held before May 3, 2024.  This referendum may be an "advisory" referendum; that is, it is not necessary for the referendum to have any legally binding effect.

It shall not be deemed resolved by a “wildcat” or “Catalan” style of referendum where the UK government has declined permission for the vote, nor by a vote organised by civil society institutions. A referendum must be deemed to have the consent of the London government

metadata.background_info:
Scotland is one of the UK’s four constituent nations - and its politics are currently dominated by the [Scottish National Party](https://whatscotlandthinks.org/), a party whose core aim is to remove Scotland from the UK and become an independent country. 

The SNP government in Edinburgh previously successfully negotiated with the UK-wide government for the right to hold a referendum, [which took place in 2014](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Scottish_independence_referendum). The “No” side (“Better Together”) won 55% to 45%. The SNP has, however, won every Scottish national election since that date.

The SNP wish to have a fresh vote - stating that Brexit has changed the terms of the argument. The UK government has, to date, refused to countenance permitting such a vote. Under the Scotland Act, the Edinburgh government does not have the power to hold one [without permission.](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1998/46/section/30)

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Scotland has not scheduled an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024. The Scottish National Party (SNP) continues to advocate for a second referendum, especially following Brexit and changes in UK leadership. However, the UK government has consistently refused to grant permission for such a referendum. In November 2022, the UK Supreme Court ruled that the Scottish Parliament does not have the authority to unilaterally hold an independence referendum without Westminster's consent. Furthermore, there have been no significant developments indicating a change in the UK government's stance. The new SNP leader, Humza Yousaf, has reiterated the desire for independence but faces the same legal and political barriers. With less than seven months until the deadline, the logistical challenges of organizing a referendum are substantial. Without a shift in the UK government's position or a legal breakthrough, it is highly unlikely that an official, sanctioned referendum will occur before May 3, 2024.

Given the current political landscape, polling data, and historical trends, the likelihood of Mike Pence being selected as the Republican nominee by the delegates at the Republican National Convention is very low.

question.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.

The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

metadata.background_info:
The 2024 Olympic games is a sporting competition which takes place every four years. It involves a range of different events across multiple sports.

At the Olympic Games, Gold, Silver and Bronze medals are awarded to 1st, 2nd and 3rd place in each event. (In some events two Bronze medals are awarded mostly combat sports).

The US team is one of the most successful teams in recent Olympics, topping the medal table in 2020, 2016, 2012, 2004, 2000. Will they repeat that in 2024?

*Related questions*

* [How many medals will Team USA win in Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7665/total-medals-won-by-the-usa-at-paris-2024/)
* [Will France come in the Top 5 at Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7669/france-home-game-advantage/

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the United States has consistently been a top performer in the Summer Olympics. In recent Olympic Games, the USA has frequently led the medal table, particularly in terms of the total number of gold medals, which is the primary ranking criterion.

At the Tokyo 2020 Olympics (held in 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic), the USA topped the medal table with 39 gold medals, narrowly surpassing China, which secured 38 gold medals. The USA also led in the total number of medals, demonstrating depth across various sports disciplines.

Looking ahead to the Paris 2024 Olympics, several factors suggest that the USA is likely to maintain its strong performance:

1. **Athlete Development:** The USA has a robust pipeline of athletes in key sports such as athletics (track and field), swimming, gymnastics, and team sports like basketball. Continued investment in training facilities and coaching should yield high-performing athletes.

2. **Historical Performance:** Historically, the USA has adapted well to different Olympic settings and has a track record of success regardless of the host country.

3. **Competition Analysis:** While China is a formidable competitor, especially in sports like gymnastics, diving, and weightlifting, the margin between the two countries has been narrow. Other countries like Russia (competing as ROC in recent Olympics) and host nation France may increase their medal counts but are less likely to surpass the USA in gold medals.

4. **Event Changes:** Any additions or removals of sports can impact medal opportunities. As of my last update, there are no significant changes that would adversely affect the USA's medal prospects.

However, uncertainties exist:

- **Emerging Competitors:** Other nations may have emerging talents that could upset predictions.
- **Injuries and Performance Variability:** Athlete injuries or unexpected performance issues can impact results.
- **Geopolitical Factors:** Political events or sanctions could influence participation, though there's no indication of this affecting the USA currently.

question.title: Will France place in the Top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if France place in the top 5 (ties resolve positively) at the Olympics being held in 2024. It will resolve ambiguously if the Olympics do not take place in 2024.

The medal table is calculated by taking the total number of medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medal

metadata.background_info:
*Related Questions on Metaculus:*

* [How many medals will Team USA win at Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7665/total-medals-won-by-the-usa-at-paris-2024/)
* [Will the Team USA top the medal table at Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7664/usa-most-successful-olympic-team-in-paris/)

----

[There is a phenomenon at the Olympics where by the host country tends to outperform it's recent performances](https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/is-there-home-field-advantage-at-the-olympics/)

France is hosting the Olympics in 2021. Will they place significantly higher in the medal table than they have in recent years. [Their last 6 placings were](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France_at_the_Olympics#Medals_by_Summer_Games):

```
2000: 6th 
2004: 7th 
2008: 10th 
2012: 7th 
2016: 7th
2020: 8th
```

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: France has historically ranked between 7th and 10th in recent Summer Olympics medal tables. In the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, France finished 8th with 10 gold medals, 12 silver, and 11 bronze medals. Hosting the Olympics often provides a significant boost to the host nation's performance due to factors like increased funding for athletes, home crowd support, and familiarity with the venues. For instance, when Great Britain hosted the 2012 Olympics, they moved up to 3rd place from 4th in 2008. Similarly, Japan, as the host nation in 2020, climbed to 3rd place from 6th in 2016.

Given that France is hosting the 2024 Paris Olympics, it's reasonable to expect an improvement in their performance. The home advantage could help French athletes secure more gold medals, which are crucial for ranking higher in the medal table. Additionally, geopolitical factors might affect the participation of strong competitors like Russia, potentially reducing competition for top medal positions.

Considering these factors—the historical performance of host nations, France's current standing, and potential changes in the competitive landscape—there is a significant likelihood that France will place in the top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

question.title: Will BJP form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the BJP has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections.  All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024)

metadata.background_info:
India has a [parliamentary government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_India) system, with 543 single-member constituencies which use first-past-the-post voting to elect MPs to the [Lok Sabha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha), the lower house in Indian Parliament.  The [Prime Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India) is appointed by the President and a majority vote of the Lok Sabha; the Prime Minister then leads this governing coalition.  Elections must be held every 5 years, but elections may be called earlier if the President dissolves the Lok Sabha.

The Bhartiya Janata Party (BJP) has been in power at the Union government level since 2014, with [Narendra Modi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi) as Prime Minister, with the Indian National Congress (INC) as the main challenger. The next national elections are scheduled for May 2024.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which party will form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024? (BJP)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the party who has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections.  All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occuring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024)

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has been the ruling party in India since 2014, securing decisive victories in both the 2014 and 2019 general elections. Under the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the BJP has maintained strong national appeal due to its emphasis on economic development, national security, and social welfare programs. The party has a robust organizational structure and substantial resources that bolster its election campaigns.

While opposition parties have made efforts to form alliances, such as the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance (INDIA), they face challenges in terms of unity, leadership, and presenting a cohesive alternative agenda. Additionally, the absence of a singular opposition leader with nationwide appeal comparable to Modi diminishes the likelihood of a significant shift in voter preference.

Considering the BJP's continued popularity, effective campaigning strategies, and the current political landscape, it is probable that the BJP will form the government after the next general election in 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has been the dominant force in Indian politics, securing decisive victories in the 2014 and 2019 general elections. While initiatives like the Bharat Jodo Yatra led by Rahul Gandhi aimed to rejuvenate the party's image, there is limited evidence to suggest a substantial shift in public support. Moreover, the fragmented opposition and the absence of a unified front against the BJP reduce the likelihood of the INC forming a government. Unless there is a significant and unforeseen change in the political landscape, the chances of the INC having a member sworn in as the next Prime Minister are low.

While external factors could influence the race—such as potential legal challenges facing Trump or shifts in voter sentiment—there is currently no strong indication that these factors will elevate Haley's candidacy to front-runner status. The Republican electorate has shown strong loyalty to Trump, and unless there are major changes in the race dynamics, it is unlikely that Haley will secure the nomination.

Taking into account her current polling position, the strength of her opponents, and the historical tendency for frontrunners to secure the nomination, the probability of Nikki Haley being selected as the Republican nominee by the Republican National Convention is low.

question.title: Will Russian athletes be barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Russian athletes are barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics under either (i) the Russian flag, (ii) The Russian Olympic Committee's flag, or (iii) any other independent or neutral flag. This will resolve based on the official list of countries and athletes present at the [2024 Olympics](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/paris-2024) or based on credible media reports, indicating that the 2024 Olympics are underway or have concluded without Russian participation. For the question to resolve as **Yes**, no more than 34 Russians can be competing at the 2024 Olympics. 34 was chosen as 10% of [Russian athletes that participated in the 2020 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Olympic_Committee_athletes_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics) to allow for a few individual or sport specific exceptions.

If more than 34 Russian athletes compete at the 2024 Olympics, this question will resolve as **No**.

If the 2024 Olympics are cancelled or postponed to 2025 or afterwards, this question resolves as ambiguously.

metadata.background_info:
After the [Russian's invasion of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine) in February 2022, Russia has been subject to a large amount of international pressure. That pressure has taken many different forms;  [sanctions](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/10266/russia-sanctions-1-year-after-invasion/), [boycotts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_boycott_of_Russia_and_Belarus), protests, oil and gas embargoes, corporate divestment, and more. Many individuals, corporations, and countries have taking action to show international solidarity with Ukraine.

In the sporting world, Russia has been banned from a number of recent international events. On Feb 28th 2022, four days after Russia invaded, FIFA made an unprecedented decision to [ban Russian clubs and the national team from all competitions](https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/mens/worldcup/qatar2022/media-releases/fifa-uefa-suspend-russian-clubs-and-national-teams-from-all-competitions) including the World Cup.

> Football is fully united here and in full solidarity with all the people affected in Ukraine. Both Presidents [FIFA and UEFA] hope that the situation in Ukraine will improve significantly and rapidly so that football can again be a vector for unity and peace amongst people.

In 2023, the IOC (International Olympic Committee) has reiterated their position several times [[1]](https://olympics.com/ioc/news/q-a-on-solidarity-with-ukraine-sanctions-against-russia-and-belarus-and-the-status-of-athletes-from-these-countries)[[2]](https://olympics.com/ioc/news/q-a-on-solidarity-with-ukraine-sanctions-against-russia-and-belarus-and-the-status-of-athletes-from-these-countries) that Russian and Belarusian athletes can only compete as Individual Neutral Athletes.

Despite IOC recommendations Poland banned Russian and Belarusian athletes from [the 2023 European Games](https://notesfrompoland.com/2023/03/29/russians-and-belarusians-banned-from-european-games-in-poland-despite-ioc-recommendations/). In Paris, the 2024 Olympic host city,  event organizers [cancelled a World Cup fencing event](https://apnews.com/article/fencing-france-russia-ukraine-2821983e726628c8bbf21e1eb8dd8c76) after the FIE (International Fencing Federation) [decision](https://apnews.com/article/fencing-russia-ukraine-olympics-9754e17d554df4484c609248019bd1a9) to allow Russian athletes to resume competing one year after the invasion of Ukraine. 

Looking back at previous Olympics, Russia's Track and Field team was [barred from the 2016 Olympics](https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/18/sports/olympics/russia-barred-rio-summer-olympics-doping.html) over a decade long doping scandal. 68 Athletes filled appeals that were ultimately [dismissed by the Court of Arbitration for Sport](https://www.nbcsports.com/bayarea/russians-lose-track-appeal-ioc-weigh-total-ban-rio), though [some](https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1133394/russia-ana-athletics) Russian athletes were able to compete as 'Authorized Neutral Athletes'. At the 2016 Paralympics the entire Russian Paralympic team was banned over the same doping scandal.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the participation of Russian athletes in the 2024 Paris Olympics is a complex and evolving issue due to geopolitical tensions stemming from Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Here is an analysis of the factors influencing the likelihood of Russian athletes being barred:

1. **International Olympic Committee (IOC) Position:**
   - The IOC has historically aimed to separate sports from politics and has often allowed athletes to compete under neutral flags when their countries face sanctions.
   - In March 2023, the IOC recommended allowing Russian and Belarusian athletes to participate as neutral competitors, provided they meet strict criteria, such as not actively supporting the war and not being affiliated with the military.

2. **Precedents:**
   - During the 2018 PyeongChang Winter Olympics and the 2020 Tokyo Olympics (held in 2021), Russian athletes competed under the designation of the Russian Olympic Committee (ROC) due to doping sanctions.
   - These precedents indicate the IOC's willingness to find compromises that allow athletes to participate while addressing broader concerns.

3. **International Pressure and Responses:**
   - Several countries and athlete groups have called for a complete ban on Russian athletes in response to the invasion of Ukraine.
   - Ukraine and some of its allies have threatened to boycott the Olympics if Russian and Belarusian athletes are allowed to compete, even under a neutral flag.
   - Despite this pressure, the IOC has emphasized the unifying power of the Olympics and the importance of not penalizing athletes for the actions of their governments.

4. **Neutral Athlete Criteria:**
   - The IOC has proposed strict eligibility criteria for Russian athletes competing as neutrals, including thorough background checks to ensure they have not supported the war or been involved in doping violations.
   - This vetting process may limit the number of eligible athletes but is unlikely to reduce the number below 34, given Russia's large pool of elite athletes.

5. **Potential Outcomes:**
   - **Full Ban:** Unlikely, as the IOC prefers inclusion and there is precedent for allowing neutral participation.
   - **Neutral Participation with Restrictions:** The most probable outcome, with Russian athletes competing under a neutral flag and without national symbols.
   - **Boycotts by Other Nations:** Possible but may not significantly impact the IOC's decision unless a large number of countries participate.

6. **Conclusion:**
   - Given the IOC's historical stance and current indications, it is likely that Russian athletes will be allowed to compete under neutral status.
   - The number of Russian athletes competing is expected to exceed 34, as Russia typically fields a large team, and even with restrictions, many athletes may meet the eligibility criteria.

question.title: Will Tim Scott be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Tim Scott is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Tim Scott)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.  All other candidates will resolve as **No**.  This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, Tim Scott, a U.S. Senator from South Carolina, is one of several candidates seeking the Republican nomination for the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election. While he has officially declared his candidacy and has participated in debates and campaign events, he is currently polling significantly behind the leading candidates.

Former President Donald Trump remains the clear frontrunner in the Republican primary race, consistently leading national and state polls by substantial margins. Florida Governor Ron DeSantis is generally considered the second-leading candidate, although his support has varied over time. Other candidates like Nikki Haley, Vivek Ramaswamy, and Mike Pence also hold portions of the voter base.

Tim Scott's polling numbers have remained in the low single digits nationally. Despite his efforts to present a unifying and optimistic message, he has not experienced a notable surge in voter support. Fundraising totals and endorsements also reflect his lower standing compared to the leading candidates.

Historically, candidates who are polling in single digits at this stage of the primary season face significant challenges in securing the nomination. While it is not impossible for a lower-polling candidate to gain momentum, it typically requires a major shift in the race dynamics, such as leading candidates withdrawing or significant events altering voter perceptions.

Considering the current state of the race, the strength of the frontrunners, and historical trends in primary elections, the likelihood of Tim Scott being selected by the delegates at the Republican National Convention as the nominee is low.

question.title: Will S&D hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the S&D holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.background_info:
The [European Parliament](https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/government_in_ireland/european_government/eu_institutions/european_parliament.html#:~:text=The%20European%20Parliament%20is%20part,member%20states%20every%205%20years.) is a key legislative body within the European Union (EU) that shares lawmaking responsibilities with the Council of the European Union. Comprising [705](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/faq/11/how-many-meps) directly elected Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) from EU member states, the Parliament holds elections every five years. While it cannot initiate legislation, the European Parliament can approve, reject, or amend proposed laws, and it also supervises EU institutions and budgets.

During [European parliamentary elections](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/at-your-service/en/be-heard/elections), candidates run as representatives of their national parties, which are typically affiliated with political groups in the European Parliament. Once elected, Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) officially join political groups based on shared ideologies and policy objectives that align with their national parties. According to the [EU Parliament website](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/about-parliament/en/organisation-and-rules/organisation/political-groups), the following political groups are currently present in the European parliament:

| Group Name | Abbreviation |
|------------|--------------|
| Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) | EPP |
| Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament | S&D |
| Renew Europe Group | RE |
| Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance | Greens/EFA |
| Identity and Democracy Group | ID |
| European Conservatives and Reformists Group | ECR |
| The Left group in the European Parliament  | GUE/NGL |

In the [2019 elections](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/election-results-2019/en), the seats were allocated as follows between the political groups: 

| Group Name | Abbreviation | Seats |
|------------|--------------|-------|
| Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) | EPP | 182 |
| Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament | S&D | 154 |
| Renew Europe Group | RE | 108 |
| Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance | Greens/EFA | 74 |
| Identity and Democracy Group | ID | 73 |
| European Conservatives and Reformists Group | ECR | 62 |
| Non-Inscrits | NI | 57 |
| Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left | GUE/NGL | 41 |
| **Total Seats** | | **751** |


The next European parliamentary elections are [scheduled for 2024](https://multimedia.europarl.europa.eu/en/package/european-elections-2024_23001), with [polling](https://europeelects.eu/ep2024/) indicating a narrow lead for the EPP in early 2023.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which political group will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections? (S&D)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the political group that holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) is currently the second-largest political group in the European Parliament, behind the European People's Party (EPP). In the 2019 elections, the EPP secured 187 seats, while the S&D obtained 147 seats.

Recent political trends in Europe indicate challenges for traditional center-left parties like those in the S&D group. They are facing increased competition from multiple fronts:

1. **Rise of Right-Wing Parties**: Countries like Italy and Sweden have seen a surge in right-wing populist parties. For instance, Italy's Brothers of Italy and Sweden Democrats have gained significant support, which may reduce the voter base for center-left parties.

2. **Growth of Liberal and Centrist Parties**: Parties affiliated with Renew Europe have been attracting voters from traditional parties. In France, for example, Emmanuel Macron's centrist party has drawn support away from both the left and right.

3. **Environmental Concerns Boosting Green Parties**: Green parties have been gaining traction in countries like Germany, drawing voters who might have previously supported the S&D.

4. **Economic and Geopolitical Factors**: Issues such as inflation, economic uncertainty, and geopolitical tensions (e.g., the war in Ukraine) may influence voters to favor conservative or incumbent parties.

Polling data up to October 2023 suggests that the EPP and S&D remain the two largest groups, but the EPP maintains a slight lead. Additionally, internal competition within the left (from Greens and more radical left parties) may further split the vote.

Given these factors, while it's possible for the S&D to gain seats, overcoming the EPP's lead appears unlikely under current circumstances.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which political group will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections? (Renew)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the political group that holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Renew Europe is the third-largest political group in the European Parliament, holding around 108 seats out of 705. The largest groups are the European People's Party (EPP) with approximately 182 seats and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) with about 154 seats. For Renew Europe to hold the most seats after the 2024 elections, they would need to surpass both the EPP and S&D, requiring a significant shift in voter support across multiple EU member states.

Current political trends and polling data suggest that while Renew Europe may gain some seats, it is unlikely they will overtake the EPP and S&D. Traditional parties aligned with the EPP and S&D continue to have strong support in key countries like Germany, Spain, and Italy. Additionally, Renew Europe's member parties face challenges; for example, in France, President Macron's party (a key member of Renew Europe) has seen fluctuating support due to domestic issues.

Furthermore, the rise of other political forces, such as right-wing populist parties and the Greens, may fragment the vote further, making it harder for any one group to gain a substantial lead. The fragmentation of liberal and centrist parties across different member states also limits the potential for a unified surge in Renew Europe's representation.

Considering these factors, the probability that Renew Europe will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections is low.

To become the largest group after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, ECR would need to surpass the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), which currently hold around 182 and 154 seats, respectively.

Recent political trends show a rise in support for right-wing and Eurosceptic parties in some EU member states. For example, the success of the Brothers of Italy (Fratelli d'Italia) led by Giorgia Meloni could boost ECR's numbers. However, these gains are unlikely to be sufficient to overtake the larger groups. Additionally, many right-wing and nationalist parties align with different groups, such as Identity and Democracy (ID), which includes parties like the National Rally in France and the League in Italy.

Significant shifts in voter behavior across multiple countries would be required for ECR to become the largest group. Such a sweeping change seems improbable given historical voting patterns and the diverse political landscapes of EU member states. There are also no major indicators suggesting a collapse of support for the largest groups like EPP and S&D.

Considering these factors, the likelihood of ECR holding the most seats after the 2024 elections is low.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which political group will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections? (ID)

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, the Identity and Democracy (ID) political group held a minority of seats in the European Parliament compared to larger groups such as the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). The ID group comprises nationalist and Eurosceptic parties, which, while having gained some support in recent years, would require a significant surge to overtake the more established political groups.

European Parliament elections are influenced by the political climates of multiple member states. While there have been instances of increasing support for nationalist parties in certain countries, this trend is not uniform across the European Union. Moreover, the proportional representation system used in these elections tends to distribute seats among a wide range of parties, making it challenging for a single group to achieve a dominant majority.

To become the largest political group, the ID would need to substantially increase its share of votes in several major EU countries. Given historical voting patterns, current polling data up to my last update, and the diverse political landscapes of member states, this seems unlikely. Additionally, mainstream parties often form coalitions to prevent extremist groups from gaining excessive influence.

question.title: Will GUE/NGL hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if GUE/NGL holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.background_info:
The [European Parliament](https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/government_in_ireland/european_government/eu_institutions/european_parliament.html#:~:text=The%20European%20Parliament%20is%20part,member%20states%20every%205%20years.) is a key legislative body within the European Union (EU) that shares lawmaking responsibilities with the Council of the European Union. Comprising [705](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/faq/11/how-many-meps) directly elected Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) from EU member states, the Parliament holds elections every five years. While it cannot initiate legislation, the European Parliament can approve, reject, or amend proposed laws, and it also supervises EU institutions and budgets.

During [European parliamentary elections](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/at-your-service/en/be-heard/elections), candidates run as representatives of their national parties, which are typically affiliated with political groups in the European Parliament. Once elected, Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) officially join political groups based on shared ideologies and policy objectives that align with their national parties. According to the [EU Parliament website](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/about-parliament/en/organisation-and-rules/organisation/political-groups), the following political groups are currently present in the European parliament:

| Group Name | Abbreviation |
|------------|--------------|
| Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) | EPP |
| Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament | S&D |
| Renew Europe Group | RE |
| Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance | Greens/EFA |
| Identity and Democracy Group | ID |
| European Conservatives and Reformists Group | ECR |
| The Left group in the European Parliament  | GUE/NGL |

In the [2019 elections](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/election-results-2019/en), the seats were allocated as follows between the political groups: 

| Group Name | Abbreviation | Seats |
|------------|--------------|-------|
| Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) | EPP | 182 |
| Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament | S&D | 154 |
| Renew Europe Group | RE | 108 |
| Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance | Greens/EFA | 74 |
| Identity and Democracy Group | ID | 73 |
| European Conservatives and Reformists Group | ECR | 62 |
| Non-Inscrits | NI | 57 |
| Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left | GUE/NGL | 41 |
| **Total Seats** | | **751** |


The next European parliamentary elections are [scheduled for 2024](https://multimedia.europarl.europa.eu/en/package/european-elections-2024_23001), with [polling](https://europeelects.eu/ep2024/) indicating a narrow lead for the EPP in early 2023.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which political group will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections? (GUE-NGL)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the political group that holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the GUE/NGL group, now known as The Left in the European Parliament, is one of the smaller political groups in the European Parliament. In the 2019 European Parliamentary Elections, they secured 41 out of 751 seats, which is approximately 5% of the total seats. The largest groups historically have been the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), which have held a significant majority of the seats.

Current polling data and political trends up to 2023 do not indicate a substantial surge in support for GUE/NGL across the member states. While there may be growing support for leftist parties in some regions, it is unlikely to be enough to surpass the well-established larger groups like the EPP, S&D, or even Renew Europe.

Moreover, political dynamics in the EU tend to change gradually, and a dramatic shift that would allow GUE/NGL to become the largest group would require unprecedented political realignments in multiple member states.

Therefore, considering the historical performance, current trends, and the political landscape of the European Union, the probability of GUE/NGL holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections is very low.

question.title: Will Linda Yaccarino be the CEO of Twitter on July 1, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Linda Yaccarino is in the position of CEO at Twitter on July 1, 2024, according to official announcements from Twitter or credible media sources.

metadata.background_info:
Linda Yaccarino, the former advertising chief of NBCUniversal, has been [appointed as the CEO of Twitter](https://edition.cnn.com/2023/05/12/tech/twitter-ceo-linda-yaccarino/index.html) by Elon Musk, the owner of the platform. She's expected to [assume the role in late June, 2023](https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1656748197308674048). The selection of Yaccarino indicates Musk's focus on Twitter's advertising business and his plans to revamp the social network into  [X, the “everything app”](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/may/11/elon-musk-twitter-new-ceo).  Yaccarino has a strong background in the advertising industry and is known for her influential role in Madison Avenue.

Assuming the role of Twitter CEO, Yaccarino will face various challenges, including Twitter's struggles to expand its advertising business, gaps in expertise and technical glitches, and the company's substantial debt. Additionally, she will have to navigate the unpredictable nature of working with Musk.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning:
Linda Yaccarino was appointed as the CEO of Twitter (now rebranded as X) in May 2023 by Elon Musk. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, she continues to serve in that role. Several factors suggest she may remain CEO on July 1, 2024:

1. **Expertise and Performance**: Yaccarino has a strong background in advertising from her tenure at NBCUniversal. Twitter/X has been focusing on monetization and advertising revenue, areas where her expertise is valuable. If she is performing well, there's less incentive to replace her.

2. **Need for Stability**: After significant leadership changes and restructuring since Elon Musk's acquisition, maintaining stability at the executive level could benefit the company. Frequent changes in leadership can disrupt operations and negatively impact employee morale and investor confidence.

3. **Elon Musk's Other Commitments**: Musk oversees multiple companies (Tesla, SpaceX, Neuralink, The Boring Company). Delegating the CEO role to Yaccarino allows him to focus on his other ventures while she manages day-to-day operations at Twitter/X.

However, there are factors that could lead to her departure before July 1, 2024:

1. **Musk's Management Style**: Elon Musk is known for his hands-on approach and willingness to make swift executive decisions. If he becomes dissatisfied with her performance or wants to change direction, he may replace her.

2. **Company Performance**: If Twitter/X fails to meet financial targets, user growth, or other key performance indicators, pressure may mount for leadership changes.

3. **Market and Regulatory Challenges**: The social media landscape is rapidly changing. New competitors, regulatory pressures, or public relations issues could impact leadership stability.

Balancing these factors, it seems moderately likely that Linda Yaccarino will remain CEO on July 1, 2024, but there is significant uncertainty due to Musk's unpredictable management style and the dynamic nature of the industry.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.background_info:
From [Reuters on May 24, 2023](https://www.reuters.com/technology/openai-may-leave-eu-if-regulations-bite-ceo-2023-05-24), "OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said on Wednesday the ChatGPT maker might consider leaving Europe if it could not comply with the upcoming artificial intelligence (AI) regulations by the European Union."

The [EU AI Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence_Act) "regulates the providers of artificial intelligence systems, and entities making use of them in a professional capacity." As of May 24, 2024, [Metaculus expects](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8787/passing-of-the-ai-act/) the AI Act to be passed between Oct 2023 and Nov 2024, with a median of April 2024, though OpenAI could choose to cease offering ChatGPT in Europe earlier than that, or for some other reason entirely.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, ChatGPT is generally available across the European Union. OpenAI has demonstrated a commitment to complying with EU regulations, including the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Earlier in 2023, there was a temporary suspension of ChatGPT in Italy due to privacy concerns, but OpenAI addressed these issues promptly, and the service was reinstated.

Looking ahead to June 30, 2024, several factors influence the availability of ChatGPT in the EU:

1. Regulatory Environment: The EU is progressing with new regulations on artificial intelligence, such as the EU AI Act. While these regulations may impose stricter requirements on AI services, OpenAI has shown adaptability in meeting legal obligations. It's reasonable to assume that OpenAI will continue to adjust its practices to comply with new regulations to maintain access in the EU market.

2. Market Incentives: The EU represents a significant user base for OpenAI. The company has strong incentives to keep ChatGPT available to EU residents, which includes investing in compliance and addressing any legal challenges that may arise.

3. Technological and Operational Factors: There are no known technological barriers that would prevent ChatGPT from being available in the EU. Operationally, OpenAI has the infrastructure to support international access.

4. Political and Social Climate: While there is growing scrutiny of AI technologies, there is also recognition of their benefits. Unless there is a major incident leading to widespread bans or public outcry, it is unlikely that ChatGPT would become unavailable in over 50% of EU countries.

Considering these factors, while acknowledging the uncertainties inherent in regulatory developments and public sentiment, the probability that ChatGPT will be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024, is high.

question.title: Will Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Larry Elder)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.  All other candidates will resolve as **No**.  This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, Larry Elder is a conservative talk radio host who entered the race for the Republican nomination for the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election. While he gained some national attention during the 2021 California gubernatorial recall election, where he was the leading Republican candidate against Governor Gavin Newsom, his national profile remains relatively low compared to other candidates.

In the current Republican primary landscape, former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis are the dominant figures, commanding the majority of media attention, fundraising, and voter support in national polls. Other notable candidates include former U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley, Senator Tim Scott, entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy, and former Vice President Mike Pence. These candidates have more substantial political experience, national recognition, and campaign infrastructures than Larry Elder.

Larry Elder's polling numbers have been consistently low on a national level, often registering at 1% or below in most reputable polls. He lacks significant endorsements from prominent Republican figures and does not have a widespread grassroots organization in key primary states. Fundraising efforts have also been limited compared to the leading candidates, which hinders his ability to compete effectively in advertising and campaign events.

Historically, candidates who are polling this low at this stage in the primary process have an exceedingly slim chance of securing the nomination. With the Republican National Convention scheduled for mid-2024, there is limited time for Larry Elder to substantially increase his support base and overcome the significant leads held by the frontrunners.

Given these factors—the dominance of other candidates, low polling numbers, limited fundraising, and lack of national recognition—it is highly unlikely that Larry Elder will be selected as the Republican nominee at the Republican National Convention.

As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Francis Suarez, the Mayor of Miami, entered the race for the Republican nomination for the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election in June 2023. However, his campaign struggled to gain traction nationally. He faced challenges in meeting the polling and fundraising thresholds required to participate in the Republican primary debates.

In August 2023, after failing to qualify for the first Republican debate, Francis Suarez announced that he was suspending his presidential campaign. This decision effectively ended his bid for the nomination. The Republican primary field remains crowded with prominent candidates such as former President Donald Trump, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, former Ambassador Nikki Haley, and entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy, among others.

The nomination process is highly competitive and typically favors candidates with substantial support, funding, and national recognition—all areas where Suarez was lacking before suspending his campaign.

Unforeseen Events: While unexpected events can dramatically alter a political race, relying on such events is speculative. There is no indication of any impending circumstance that would significantly boost Hurd's candidacy.

Considering all these factors—low polling numbers, limited fundraising, lack of debate participation, historical precedent, and the current political climate—the probability of Will Hurd becoming the Republican nominee is extremely low.

question.title: Will Anthropic publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, Anthropic publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.background_info:
On July 21, 2023, the White House announced ([fact sheet](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2023/07/21/fact-sheet-biden-harris-administration-secures-voluntary-commitments-from-leading-artificial-intelligence-companies-to-manage-the-risks-posed-by-ai/), [full report](https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Ensuring-Safe-Secure-and-Trustworthy-AI.pdf)) that Amazon, Anthropic, Google, Inflection, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI have voluntarily committed to manage AI risks.

The voluntary commitments are in three categories (a) "Ensuring Products are Safe Before Introducing Them to the Public", (b) "Building Systems that Put Security First", and (c) "Earning the Public’s Trust", and are "designed to advance a generative AI legal and policy regime".

From [Microsoft](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/openai/concepts/red-teaming), "historically described systematic adversarial attacks for testing security vulnerabilities. With the rise of LLMs, the term has extended beyond traditional cybersecurity and evolved in common usage to describe many kinds of probing, testing, and attacking of AI systems." Note that this question only asks about _safety_, not _security_. [Google](https://bughunters.google.com/about/rules/6625378258649088/google-and-alphabet-vulnerability-reward-program-vrp-rules) and [OpenAI](https://bugcrowd.com/openai) already have bug bounties for security.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Will these AI labs publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024? (Anthropic)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body: For each AI lab, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, Anthropic is a company that places a strong emphasis on AI safety and ethics. They have been active in research and discussions around AI alignment and responsible AI deployment. Given the increasing global focus on AI safety, transparency, and regulation, there is a growing trend for AI companies to engage in external audits and publish their findings to build public trust.

External red-teaming involves independent parties testing AI models to identify vulnerabilities or unintended behaviors. Publishing a report on such activities demonstrates a commitment to transparency and accountability. Other major AI organizations, like OpenAI and DeepMind, have engaged in similar practices, indicating industry movement toward greater openness.

However, there are factors that might influence whether Anthropic will publish such a report by June 30, 2024. These include:

- **Confidentiality Concerns**: Sharing detailed findings might risk revealing proprietary information or expose the company to competitive disadvantages.
- **Resource Allocation**: Organizing external red-teaming and preparing public reports require significant resources and coordination.
- **Regulatory Environment**: Depending on how regulations evolve, Anthropic might choose to wait for clearer guidelines before publishing such reports.

Considering Anthropic's commitment to AI safety and the industry's trend toward transparency, there is a reasonable likelihood that they will publish a report with results from external red-teaming by the specified date.

question.title: Will Google DeepMind publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: For Google DeepMind, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.background_info:
On July 21, 2023, the White House announced ([fact sheet](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2023/07/21/fact-sheet-biden-harris-administration-secures-voluntary-commitments-from-leading-artificial-intelligence-companies-to-manage-the-risks-posed-by-ai/), [full report](https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Ensuring-Safe-Secure-and-Trustworthy-AI.pdf)) that Amazon, Anthropic, Google, Inflection, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI have voluntarily committed to manage AI risks.

The voluntary commitments are in three categories (a) "Ensuring Products are Safe Before Introducing Them to the Public", (b) "Building Systems that Put Security First", and (c) "Earning the Public’s Trust", and are "designed to advance a generative AI legal and policy regime".

From [Microsoft](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/openai/concepts/red-teaming), "historically described systematic adversarial attacks for testing security vulnerabilities. With the rise of LLMs, the term has extended beyond traditional cybersecurity and evolved in common usage to describe many kinds of probing, testing, and attacking of AI systems." Note that this question only asks about _safety_, not _security_. [Google](https://bughunters.google.com/about/rules/6625378258649088/google-and-alphabet-vulnerability-reward-program-vrp-rules) and [OpenAI](https://bugcrowd.com/openai) already have bug bounties for security.
