question.title: Will Donald Trump be charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024?
question.body: The question resolves **Yes** if Donald Trump is charged or indicted for any statements related to potential witnesses in *[The State of Georgia v. Donald J. Trump, et al](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_Georgia)*. The indictments must occur before June 1, 2024.

metadata.background_info:
On August 14, 2023, former President Donald Trump was [indicted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_Georgia#Indictment) by a grand jury in Georgia, alongside 18 other individuals. The state brought charges against Trump related to Trump's alleged participation in an attempt to overturn the state's 2020 presidential election results.

Trump made statements on his social media platform, Truth Social, which [appeared to warn](https://www.axios.com/2023/08/14/trump-witness-tampering-georgia-indictment) potential witnesses not to testify against him.

> Former President Donald Trump posted on Truth Social, his social media platform, on Monday saying Georgia’s former Lt. Gov. Geoff Duncan “shouldn’t” testify in grand jury proceedings this week regarding allegations that Trump attempted to overturn the 2020 election results in the state—and some legal analysts are saying the post could be witness intimidation or tampering.

> ...

> Per Georgia law, anyone who attempts to [influence](https://law.justia.com/codes/georgia/2020/title-16/chapter-10/article-5/section-16-10-93/) a witness is subject to felony charges and, if convicted, can face one to five years in prison; anyone who [threatens](https://law.justia.com/codes/georgia/2022/title-16/chapter-10/article-2/section-16-10-32/#:~:text=Attempted%20Murder%20or%20Threatening%20of%20Witnesses%20in%20Official%20Proceedings,-Universal%20Citation%3A%20GA&text=shall%20be%20guilty%20of%20a,nor%20more%20than%2020%20years.) a witness is subject to felony charges and, if convicted, faces 10 to 20 years in prison. ([Forbes](https://www.forbes.com/sites/mollybohannon/2023/08/14/trump-suggested-a-witness-shouldnt-testify-in-georgias-grand-jury-proceedings-critics-say-thats-witness-intimidation/?sh=7e14b52a57be))

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Donald Trump has been indicted in Georgia on charges related to his efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election results. The indictment includes multiple counts under Georgia's Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act, but it does not specifically include charges of witness tampering.

For Donald Trump to be charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024, the following factors would be relevant:

1. **Ongoing Investigations**: The legal proceedings and investigations are ongoing. Prosecutors may uncover new evidence that could lead to additional charges, including witness tampering.

2. **Potential Evidence of Tampering**: If there are allegations or evidence that Trump attempted to influence or intimidate witnesses involved in the case after the indictment was issued, this could prompt new charges.

3. **Legal Strategy**: Prosecutors might decide to broaden the case if they believe additional charges strengthen their position or address new developments.

4. **Time Frame**: There are several months until June 1, 2024, which allows time for new charges to be filed if warranted.

However, there are also factors that may reduce the likelihood:

1. **Focus on Existing Charges**: Prosecutors might prefer to focus on the current charges to keep the case streamlined and avoid delays.

2. **Lack of Public Allegations**: As of October 2023, there have been no public allegations or credible reports specifically accusing Trump of witness tampering in Georgia.

3. **Legal Threshold**: Charging someone with witness tampering requires specific evidence of intent to influence or intimidate a witness improperly.

Considering the above, while it is possible that new charges could be brought, there is no concrete information suggesting that witness tampering charges against Trump in Georgia are imminent or likely before June 1, 2024.

question.title: Will Erling Haaland score the most goals in the 2023/24 Premier League season?
question.body: The question resolves **Yes** if Erling Haaland is the player with the largest number of goals after each of the 20 PL teams plays their 38th game of the 2023/24 season, [according to Oracle Cloud via the PL website](https://www.premierleague.com/stats/top/players/goals?se=578)

metadata.background_info: Erling Haaland plays for Manchester City, a football team which competes in a number of competitions, including the Premier League.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Erling Haaland had an exceptional 2022/23 Premier League season, finishing as the top scorer with a record-breaking number of goals. Playing for Manchester City, a team renowned for its attacking prowess and creative midfielders, he benefits from ample goal-scoring opportunities. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Haaland has started the 2023/24 season in strong form, continuing his impressive goal-scoring streak. Additionally, some of his main competitors for the Golden Boot, such as Harry Kane, have left the Premier League (e.g., Kane's transfer to Bayern Munich). While there are always uncertainties like potential injuries or dips in form, Haaland's track record, team support, and the reduced competition make him the clear favorite to be the top scorer this season.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.background_info:
*This question is modeled on [this Metaculus question](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/18606/trump-removed-or-blocked-from-the-ballot/), but asks instead about the possibility of Trump's removal from primary election ballots.*

The 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution has a section known as the "Disqualification Clause" or Section 3, which may disqualify individuals from holding federal or state office if they have "engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the [U.S.], or given aid or comfort to the enemies thereof." Given the events surrounding the January 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, this section has become a subject of considerable debate with respect to former President Donald Trump's eligibility to run for federal office again.

In New Hampshire, Bryant "Corky" Messner, an attorney who ran for U.S. Senate in 2020 with Trump's endorsement, has [expressed intentions to file a legal challenge](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisondurkee/2023/08/29/trump-14th-amendment-new-hampshire-gop-feuds-as-states-grapple-with-disqualifying-trump-from-ballot/?sh=70038b512e9a) questioning Trump's 2024 candidacy under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The Republican Secretary of State of New Hampshire, David Scanlan, while not actively seeking to remove any candidates, has stated that he will seek legal advice on the issue. Additionally, Michigan’s Democratic Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson has indicated that she will seek a legal opinion on this matter. Voters have also filed lawsuits in Florida and Michigan on the issue. Legal battles are widely expected, and these disputes might reach the U.S. Supreme Court.

This question focuses on whether these and similar ongoing discussions and legal challenges will result in Donald Trump being removed from the primary election ballot of any state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15th, 2024, the planned start of the 2024 Republican National Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been discussions and legal debates about the applicability of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to former President Donald Trump, particularly in light of the events on January 6, 2021. Some legal scholars and advocacy groups argue that his actions surrounding the Capitol riot constitute "insurrection or rebellion," which could disqualify him from holding federal office.

Several factors influence the probability of Trump being removed or blocked from any state primary ballot under this provision by July 15, 2024:

1. Legal Precedent and Challenges:
   - Historical Precedent: The use of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify a candidate has been rare and not tested in modern times, especially for a presidential candidate.
   - Legal Challenges: Any attempt to remove Trump from a ballot would almost certainly face immediate legal challenges. The judicial process could be lengthy, potentially extending beyond the specified date.

2. State Actions:
   - State Variations: Individual states have different laws and processes for candidate qualification. Some states might be more inclined to pursue disqualification efforts, but they would need solid legal grounds.
   - Political Considerations: State officials, especially in states with Republican leadership, may be reluctant to remove a leading candidate from the ballot without unequivocal legal justification.

3. Ongoing Efforts:
   - Advocacy Groups: As of 2023, certain groups are actively seeking to disqualify Trump using Section 3. Lawsuits have been filed in some states aiming to prevent his candidacy.
   - Court Decisions: Early court rulings on related cases could set precedents. However, as of my last update, no court has definitively ruled on Trump's disqualification under this section.

4. Timing Constraints:
   - Legal Proceedings Duration: Given the complexity, legal proceedings might not conclude before July 15, 2024.
   - Appeals Process: Even if a lower court rules for disqualification, appeals could stay the decision, keeping Trump on the ballot until higher courts decide.

5. Reinstatement Possibility:
   - Reinstatement Before Deadline: If Trump is removed but later reinstated before July 15, 2024, the question would resolve as "No" per the provided conditions.

Considering the above factors, while there is a non-zero possibility that efforts to remove Trump from a state primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment may occur, the likelihood of such removal being officially in effect on July 15, 2024, is relatively low. The combination of legal uncertainties, potential for protracted court battles, and political implications make it unlikely that any state will have successfully and conclusively removed him from the ballot under this provision by the specified date.

question.title: Will Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Glenn Youngkin)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.  All other candidates will resolve as **No**.  This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Glenn Youngkin is the Republican governor of Virginia who gained national attention after his 2021 gubernatorial victory in a state that had been trending Democratic. His success was attributed to his appeal to suburban voters and his focus on education and economic issues.

Despite speculation about his potential as a presidential candidate, Youngkin has not declared his candidacy for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination. The Republican primary field is already crowded with prominent figures, including former President Donald Trump, who is leading in national polls, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, former Vice President Mike Pence, former South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley, and businessman Vivek Ramaswamy, among others.

For Glenn Youngkin to become the Republican nominee, several unlikely events would need to occur:

1. **Entry into the Race**: Youngkin would need to announce his candidacy soon to build a national campaign infrastructure, which becomes increasingly difficult as key primary dates approach.

2. **Overcoming Established Candidates**: He would need to surpass candidates with greater national name recognition, fundraising capabilities, and established voter bases.

3. **Shifts in Voter Sentiment**: There would need to be significant changes in voter preferences away from current frontrunners due to unforeseen events or scandals.

4. **Support from Party Leaders**: While some party leaders might view Youngkin as a unifying figure, consolidating enough delegate support without prior campaign momentum is challenging.

Historically, late entrants into presidential races rarely secure the nomination unless there are extraordinary circumstances. Given the current dynamics of the Republican Party and the strong support for Donald Trump among the base, the probability of Glenn Youngkin being selected as the nominee by the Republican National Convention is very low.

question.title: Will the Milwaukee Bucks win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body:
The question resolves as **Yes** if the Milwaukee Bucks are crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). 

It resolves as **No** for all other teams and if the Bucks are eliminated from contention.

metadata.background_info: [The Milwaukee Bucks, Boston Celtics, Denver Nuggets and Phoenix Suns have the best odds as of the preseason.](https://sports.betmgm.com/en/blog/nba/finals-odds-championship-nba-betting-bm05/) There is a steep drop-off after that, though the Golden State Warriors and Los Angeles Lakers also have decent odds and multiple future Hall-of-Famers.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which team will win the 2024 NBA Finals? (Milwaukee Bucks)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
The question resolves Yes for the team that is crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). 

It resolves No for all other teams as they are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, the Milwaukee Bucks are considered one of the top contenders for the 2024 NBA Finals. Several factors contribute to their favorable outlook: 1. **Roster Strength**: The Bucks have a strong core led by two-time MVP Giannis Antetokounmpo. In the 2023 offseason, they acquired All-Star guard Damian Lillard in a high-profile trade, significantly enhancing their offensive capabilities. The pairing of Giannis and Lillard creates a formidable duo that can challenge any defense in the league. 2. **Supporting Cast**: Alongside their star players, the Bucks have a solid supporting cast, including Khris Middleton, Brook Lopez, and Jrue Holiday (though note that Holiday was traded to acquire Lillard; but as of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, Holiday was still with the team). question.title: Will Real Madrid win the 2023/2024 UEFA Champions League?
question.body: The question resolves "Yes" if Real Madrid wins the Final on the 1st of June 2024, according to [UEFA](https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/). All other teams resolve "No".

metadata.background_info: [The UEFA Champions League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League) (previously known as the European Cup, abbreviated as UCL, or sometimes, UEFA CL) is an annual club association football competition organised by the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA) and contested by top-division European clubs, deciding the competition winners through a round robin group stage to qualify for a double-legged knockout format, and a single leg final. The 2023/24 edition features 32 teams, with the final being played on the 1st of June 2024 at Wembley Stadium.

Additionally, any new signings made during the summer transfer window leading up to the 2023/2024 season could further strengthen the team.

Managerial Situation:
Under the guidance of a top-tier manager (as of my last update, Thomas Tuchel was appointed in early 2023), Bayern's tactical prowess and experience in European competitions are significant assets. The coaching staff's ability to navigate the challenges of the Champions League is crucial to their success.

Competition:
The UEFA Champions League is highly competitive, with other elite clubs vying for the title. Teams like Manchester City, Real Madrid, Barcelona, Liverpool, Paris Saint-Germain, and others pose significant challenges. Manchester City, the defending champions from the 2022/2023 season, are particularly strong competitors.

Injury and Form Factors:
Player fitness and form throughout the season can impact Bayern's chances. Injuries to key players or dips in performance can hinder progress in knockout stages, where margins are slim.

Historical Probability:
Historically, even the strongest teams have a relatively low probability of winning the Champions League due to its unpredictable nature and the quality of competition. It's rare for any single team to have a probability higher than 20% at the start of the tournament.

Conclusion:
Considering Bayern Munich's strong squad, managerial expertise, and historical success, they are among the favorites to win the tournament. However, the stiff competition and unpredictability of knockout football reduce the likelihood of any single team winning.

question.title: Will Borussia Dortmund win the 2023/2024 UEFA Champions League?
question.body: The question resolves **Yes** if Borussia Dortmund wins the Final on the 1st of June 2024, according to [UEFA](https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/). All other teams will resolve as **No**.

metadata.background_info: [The UEFA Champions League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League) (previously known as the European Cup, abbreviated as UCL, or sometimes, UEFA CL) is an annual club association football competition organised by the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA) and contested by top-division European clubs, deciding the competition winners through a round robin group stage to qualify for a double-legged knockout format, and a single leg final. The 2023/24 edition features 32 teams, with the final being played on the 1st of June 2024 at Wembley Stadium.

However, the UEFA Champions League is one of the most competitive football tournaments in the world, featuring elite clubs from across Europe. Teams such as Manchester City, Real Madrid, Bayern Munich, Paris Saint-Germain, and Barcelona are often considered favorites to win the competition due to their strong squad depth, financial resources, and recent performances in European competitions.

Borussia Dortmund has not won the Champions League since 1997 and, while they have reached the later stages of the tournament in some recent seasons, they have not consistently been among the top contenders. Factors that may impact their chances include:

- Squad Depth: Compared to some of the wealthier clubs, Dortmund may lack the depth required to compete on multiple fronts throughout the season.

- Injuries and Form: Football seasons are unpredictable, and injuries to key players or dips in form can significantly affect outcomes.

Considering these factors, while it's possible for Borussia Dortmund to win the Champions League, it would be considered an underdog victory.

question.title: Will the maximum weekly rate of hospitalizations per 100,000 in the US occur within four weeks of the combined peak for each of COVID, influenza, and RSV in the 2023-24 season?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the maximum weekly rate of hospitalizations per 100,000 for each of COVID, influenza, and RSV that occurs in the 2023-24 season is less than or equal to four weeks (28 days) from the date of the maximum rate for all three combined, according to the CDC's [RESP-NET](https://www.cdc.gov/surveillance/resp-net/dashboard.html). The four weeks will be based on the week end dates. The CDC uses "epidemiological weeks" which begin on Sunday and end on Saturday. The rate used will be that for all ages, races, and sexes. See the fine print for the correct filters. For the purposes of this question, the 2023-2024 season will be considered to begin with the week ending on October 7, 2023, and end on the week ending June 1, 2024.

To allow for data revisions and reporting delays the question will resolve according to data shown after the reporting delay period, when the relevant figures for the current season is not shown as a dashed line, typically 4 weeks after the week end date.

metadata.background_info:
The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) closely monitors respiratory illnesses, particularly when these illnesses increase in prevalence during the winter. One monitoring and data sharing tool the CDC uses is [RESP-NET](https://www.cdc.gov/surveillance/resp-net/dashboard.html), which it describes as follows:

>The Respiratory Virus Hospitalization Surveillance Network (RESP-NET) comprises three networks that conduct population-based surveillance for laboratory-confirmed hospitalizations associated with COVID-19, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), and influenza among children and adults. While RESP-NET does not collect data on all hospitalizations caused by respiratory illnesses, it can describe hospitalizations caused by three viruses that account for a large proportion of these hospitalizations. Surveillance is conducted through a network of acute care hospitals in select counties or county equivalents in 12 states for RSV surveillance, 13 states for COVID-19 surveillance, and 14 states for influenza surveillance. The surveillance platforms for COVID-19, RSV, and influenza (known as [COVID-NET](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/covid-net/purpose-methods.html), [RSV-NET](https://www.cdc.gov/rsv/research/rsv-net/overview-methods.html), and [FluSurv-NET](https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/influenza-hospitalization-surveillance.htm), respectively) cover more than 30 million people and include an estimated 8-10% of the U.S. population.

The underlying source data for the RESP-NET dashboard can be found at [this link](https://data.cdc.gov/Public-Health-Surveillance/Rates-of-Laboratory-Confirmed-RSV-COVID-19-and-Flu/kvib-3txy).

In its [Respiratory Disease Season Outlook](https://www.cdc.gov/respiratory-viruses/whats-new/2023-2024-season-outlook.html) for 2023-24, the CDC describes the 2022-23 peak as a "tripledemic" due to high incidence of COVID, flu, and RSV at the same time. The [RESP-NET](https://www.cdc.gov/surveillance/resp-net/dashboard.html) figures for the 2022-23 season show a large combined peak hospitalization rate of 22.2 per 100,000 for the week ending December 3, 2022, coinciding with the maximum rate for flu and less than a month from the maximum rate for RSV which occurred during the week ending November 12, 2022, and also less than a month from the maximum rate for COVID which occurred on the week ending December 31, 2022.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Based on historical patterns, the peak hospitalization rates for COVID-19, influenza, and RSV in the United States tend to occur during the fall and winter months, particularly between December and February. Respiratory viruses often surge during these times due to colder weather and increased indoor gatherings.

In the 2022-2023 season, there was notable overlap in the peaks of these illnesses, sometimes referred to as a "tripledemic." This suggests that simultaneous or closely timed peaks are possible. Additionally, factors such as waning immunity, changes in mitigation measures, and variations in virus strains can influence the timing of outbreaks.

Given that the 2023-2024 season falls within similar parameters and considering the four-week window specified, it's plausible that the maximum weekly hospitalization rates for each virus could occur within four weeks of the combined peak. However, uncertainties remain due to potential changes in public health policies, vaccination rates, and virus mutation.

question.title: Will Tyson Fury defeat Oleksandr Usyk to become the Undisputed Heavyweight Boxing Champion?
question.body: The question resolves Yes if Tyson Fury wins the boxing bout against Oleksandr Usyk. It will resolve No if Usyk wins or there is a draw. If there is no fight between the two boxers before May 19th, 2024, the question is annulled.

metadata.background_info:
The heavyweight matchup is scheduled to take place on 18 May 2024 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. This fight will be for the [undisputed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undisputed_championship_(boxing)) heavyweight champion. Both fighters are currently undefeated in their professional careers. 

According to Wikipedia: 

>[Tyson Luke Fury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyson_Fury), "Gypsy King" (born 12 August 1988) is a British professional boxer. He has held the World Boxing Council (WBC) heavyweight title since 2020. 

>Height	6 ft 9 in (206 cm)
Reach	85 in (216 cm)
Stance	Orthodox
Boxing record
Total fights	35
Wins	34
Wins by KO	24
Draws	1



>[Oleksandr Oleksandrovych Usyk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oleksandr_Usyk) (Ukrainian: Олекса́ндр Олекса́ндрович У́сик; born 17 January 1987) is a Ukrainian professional boxer. He has held multiple world championships in two weight classes, including the unified heavyweight titles since 2021, and the Ring magazine title since 2022. He has also held the International Boxing Organization (IBO) title since 2021. 

>Height	6 ft 3 in (191 cm)
Reach	78 in (198 cm)
Stance	Southpaw
Boxing record
Total fights	21
Wins	21
Wins by KO	14

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Tyson Fury and Oleksandr Usyk are the current holders of all major heavyweight boxing titles, making a unification bout between them highly anticipated. Both fighters have expressed interest in facing each other to become the undisputed heavyweight champion. Negotiations have been ongoing, but as of now, no official date has been set for the fight.

There is a significant likelihood that the fight will occur before May 19th, 2024, given the commercial appeal and the boxing world's demand for an undisputed champion. Scheduling and promotional hurdles are common in boxing, but a timeframe of several months makes it plausible for agreements to be reached.

In terms of the matchup, Tyson Fury holds advantages in height, reach, and size. He stands at 6'9" with an 85-inch reach, and has shown exceptional boxing skills, mobility, and ring intelligence for a fighter of his size. Fury's victories over top heavyweight contenders, including his trilogy with Deontay Wilder, demonstrate his ability to perform at the highest level.

Oleksandr Usyk, while an undefeated and highly skilled boxer, is a former cruiserweight who moved up to heavyweight. He secured impressive wins against Anthony Joshua, showcasing his technical prowess, speed, and endurance. However, against Fury, Usyk would be at a notable size disadvantage, which could be a significant factor in the fight.

Considering the likelihood of the fight taking place before the specified date and analyzing the strengths and weaknesses of both fighters, I estimate:

- Probability the fight happens before May 19th, 2024: 70%
- Probability Tyson Fury wins if the fight happens: 60%
- Combined probability of Tyson Fury defeating Oleksandr Usyk before May 19th, 2024: 0.7 * 0.6 = 0.42

question.title: Will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district (previously held by Bill Johnson) in the 2024 special election?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for OH's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

metadata.background_info:
In early January 2024, Rep. Bill Johnson communicated to the Governor of Ohio that he would be vacating his congressional seat effective of the 21st of January 2024 in order to take up position as the 10th President of Youngstown State University. 

On the 4th of January, [Governor DeWine announced ] (https://governor.ohio.gov/media/news-and-media/governor-dewine-calls-special-election-for-ohios-6th-congressional-district) that the special election process was scheduled as followed: partisan primary elections will happen on the 19th of March, and the general election will happen on the 11th June 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Ohio's 6th congressional district has been represented by Republican Bill Johnson since 2011. The district is known to be a Republican stronghold due to its conservative-leaning demographics and consistent support for Republican candidates in both federal and state elections. In recent election cycles, Republican candidates have won this district by significant margins, indicating strong party loyalty among the electorate.

There have been no significant demographic shifts or political realignments reported up to my knowledge cutoff that would suggest a change in voter preference. Additionally, unless there are unforeseen events affecting the popularity of the Republican Party in this district, it is reasonable to expect that the party will retain the seat in the upcoming special election scheduled before January 1, 2025.

question.title: Will a terrorist act occur in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics?
question.body:
The question will resolve as Yes if a terrorist attack in [Metropolitan France](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_France) injures and/or kills at least one person, other than the terrorist(s), between, and inclusive of, the day of the Opening Ceremony (26 July 2024) and the day of the Closing Ceremony (11 August 2024). The question will resolve as No if the above does not happen.

An event will be considered a 'terrorist attack' if it is described as such by any agency of the State of France, or by the French President, Prime Minister, or a member of the Council of Ministers.

metadata.background_info:
The most serious attack occurred at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, Germany.  Five of the hostage takers were killed, along with eleven members of the Israeli Olympic Team and one West German policeman.
At the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, a bombing at the Centennial Olympic Park resulted in one death and over 100 injuries.  This was classified as domestic terrorism. [Centennial Olympic Park bombing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centennial_Olympic_Park_bombing)
At the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, a knife attack at a Beijing market left [three people dead and over 60 injured]((https://www.start.umd.edu/news/olympics-and-terrorism). Although it did not occur during the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, Korea, the bombing of Korean Air Flight 858 on November 29, 1987 was [considered to be a terrorist attack by North Korea]( https://www.history.com/news/1988-seoul-olympics-north-korea-terrorist-attack) in an attempt to get the Olympics moved from Seoul.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning:

1. **Historical Context**: France has experienced several terrorist attacks in the past decade, notably the 2015 Paris attacks and the 2016 Nice truck attack. These incidents highlight that France has been a target for terrorist activities.

2. **Recent Trends**: In the years leading up to 2023, there has been a decrease in the frequency and severity of terrorist attacks in France. Increased counter-terrorism efforts and improved intelligence have contributed to this decline.

3. **High-Profile Event Risk**: The 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris is a global event attracting international attention. Such events are considered potential targets for terrorist groups aiming to maximize impact and media coverage.

4. **Security Measures**: The French government is likely to implement extensive security protocols for the Olympics, including increased law enforcement presence, surveillance, and collaboration with international intelligence agencies to prevent potential attacks.

5. **Threat Level**: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, France remains on alert for terrorist threats, but there have been no major attacks recently. The general threat level is moderate due to ongoing global terrorism concerns.

6. **Terrorist Motivations**: Terrorist organizations may view the Olympics as an opportunity, but operational challenges posed by heightened security might deter planning and execution.

7. **Unpredictability**: While security efforts are significant, the possibility of a lone-wolf attack or a small-scale incident cannot be entirely ruled out.

Considering the above factors, while there is a non-negligible risk of a terrorist attack during the Olympics in metropolitan France, the probability is relatively low due to heightened security and preventive measures.

question.title: Will Individual Neutral Athletes Win ≥21 Gold Medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Individual Neutral Athletes collectively win 21 or more gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games. The source of resolution will be the official medal tally published by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) or other [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) if such reporting from the IOC is unavailable. Otherwise the market will resolve to "No". 

In the event that Individual Neutral Athletes are confirmed to have won 21 or more gold medals prior to the end of the Games, the market will resolve immediately to "Yes".

metadata.background_info:
As per the Olympic Committee’s [recommendations](https://olympics.com/ioc/news/strict-eligibility-conditions-in-place-as-ioc-eb-approves-individual-neutral-athletes-ains-for-the-olympic-games-paris-2024) from earlier this year, Russian and Belarusian athletes will be allowed to participate in the 2024 Games as long as they do so as so-called "Individual Neutral Athletes" (AINs), without an accompanying national flag or anthem.

The Russian Federation/Russian Olympic Committee has won an average of 19 gold medals in the last 3 Olympic Games, and Belarus has averaged  1.7.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the participation of Russian and Belarusian athletes in the Paris 2024 Olympics is uncertain due to ongoing geopolitical tensions related to the conflict in Ukraine. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has been deliberating on whether to allow athletes from Russia and Belarus to compete as neutrals under strict conditions.

In previous Olympic Games, when Russian athletes competed under a neutral flag due to doping sanctions (e.g., as the 'Russian Olympic Committee' in Tokyo 2020), they performed strongly. At the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, athletes from the Russian Olympic Committee won 20 gold medals. This suggests that if allowed to compete, Russian athletes have the capability to win 21 or more gold medals collectively.

However, several factors contribute to uncertainty:

1. **Participation Status**: There is significant international pressure to ban Russian and Belarusian athletes due to the ongoing conflict. If they are not allowed to participate, the probability drops to zero.

2. **Conditions of Participation**: Even if permitted, restrictions might limit the number of athletes or the events they can participate in, potentially reducing their medal prospects.

3. **Athlete Preparation**: The conflict and related sanctions may have affected the training and preparation of athletes from these countries.

Considering these factors, while there is a possibility that Individual Neutral Athletes could collectively win 21 or more gold medals if they participate without major restrictions, the uncertainties reduce the overall probability.

question.title: Will Iran carry out a deadly attack within Israel before May 1, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves **Yes** if, following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, credible reports indicate that an attack attributed to Iran and occurring within Israel's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

metadata.background_info:
On April 1, 2024, an Israeli airstrike [targeted the Iranian embassy](https://apnews.com/article/israel-syria-airstrike-iranian-embassy-edca34c52d38c8bc57281e4ebf33b240) in Damascus, Syria, resulting in significant casualties including the deaths of top Iranian commanders. 

In the aftermath, the United States has increased its security posture in the region, anticipating a retaliatory strike by Iran against Israeli or American assets. Senior U.S. and Israeli officials [consider such an attack "inevitable."](https://www.cnn.com/2024/04/05/politics/us-israel-iran-retaliation-strike/index.html)

metadata.chain_of_thought: The longstanding tensions between Iran and Israel up to late 2023 have been characterized by indirect confrontations rather than direct attacks. Iran typically operates through proxy groups like Hezbollah in Lebanon and Hamas in the Gaza Strip to influence regional dynamics and apply pressure on Israel. Direct attacks by Iran within Israel's borders are rare due to the significant risk of escalation and international repercussions. The specified time frame from April 10, 2024, to May 1, 2024, is relatively short—about three weeks. Without specific intelligence or events indicating an imminent attack planned by Iran during this period, and considering Israel's robust security and intelligence capabilities, the likelihood of such a direct and deadly attack occurring is low. Additionally, any major operation would likely be detectable by international observers and could prompt preemptive measures.

question.title: Will Israel expand its ground invasion to the city of Rafah before June 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve **Yes** if the [Institute for the Study of War](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/2e746151991643e39e64780f0674f7dd) (ISW) reports Israeli military operations on its map at any of six locations surrounding Rafah (the specific locations are shown in the map embedded below) before June 1, 2024.

<iframe src="https://www.google.com/maps/d/u/0/embed?mid=1VCJMA9AH4k8G6v33Yr6z254_umiNe4Q&ehbc=2E312F" width="640" height="480"}}>
</iframe>

metadata.background_info:
The [Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israeli_invasion_of_the_Gaza_Strip_(2023–present)#27_October) commenced on October 27, 2023 in response to a [Hamas-led attack on Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Hamas-led_attack_on_Israel) on October 7, 2023 which saw over a thousand killed, and hundreds kidnapped.

The invasion was initially limited to Northern Gaza, but the plans were gradually expanded further South. Recently, Israel has [stated its intentions to expand its invasion to the Southern city of Rafah](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2024-02-12/israel-conducts-strikes-in-rafah-as-humanitarian-concerns-mount), which borders Egypt. These expansion plans, like prior ones, have seen widespread condemnation from both pro and anti-Israeli nations. This condemnation is primarily based on the alarming number of deaths and casualties stemming from the ground invasion; the growing humanitarian crisis, which has become more acute as the Israeli invasion has expanded; and the vast number of Palestinian refugees which are reportedly taking refuge in the city having fled from Northern Gaza.

Israel has already [commenced airstrikes and covert raids in Rafah](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2024-02-12/israel-conducts-strikes-in-rafah-as-humanitarian-concerns-mount), but a full-scale ground invasion has yet to commence.

Amongst the nations who have condemned the plans are the US - Israel's closest ally - and Egypt - Gaza's Southern neighbour which [has threatened](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/02/11/egypt-threatens-to-suspend-key-peace-treaty-if-israel-pushes-into-rafah-on-its-border-officials-say.html) to break it's 45 year old peace treaty with Israel if the ground invasion plans commence in Rafah.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has continued to state that an invasion is imminent and that Israel has a specific date set, though on April 9 it [was reported](https://www.axios.com/2024/04/09/israel-defense-gallant-deny-rafah-invasion-date) that Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant has said there is no date set.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Israel and Hamas are engaged in a significant escalation of conflict following attacks by Hamas on Israeli territory. Israel has mobilized forces and initiated air strikes in the Gaza Strip, with indications of potential ground operations to dismantle Hamas's military capabilities.

Rafah is a city located at the southern border of the Gaza Strip, adjacent to Egypt. It is strategically important due to the presence of tunnels and smuggling routes that have been used to transport weapons and supplies into Gaza. Given Israel's objective to eliminate Hamas's infrastructure and prevent the rearmament of the group, extending ground operations to Rafah could be considered a strategic move to cut off these supply lines.

However, several factors might influence this decision:

1. **International Pressure:** There is significant international concern regarding civilian casualties and humanitarian conditions in Gaza. Expanding military operations to densely populated areas like Rafah could exacerbate these concerns and lead to increased diplomatic pressure on Israel to restrain its military actions.

2. **Egypt's Role:** Rafah borders Egypt, and any military activity near the Egyptian border could strain Israel-Egypt relations. Egypt has been a mediator in previous conflicts and may oppose extensive military operations in Rafah to prevent destabilization along its border.

3. **Operational Challenges:** Urban warfare in densely populated cities poses significant risks to military personnel and civilians. The Israeli Defense Forces may weigh these risks against the strategic benefits of operating in Rafah.

Considering the time frame until June 1, 2024, there is ample time for the situation to evolve. If the conflict persists and Israel remains committed to dismantling Hamas's capabilities comprehensively, it is plausible that ground operations could extend to Rafah. However, the factors mentioned above introduce uncertainty.

question.title: Will Albania qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Albania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. The question will resolve as **No** for all other outcomes regarding Albania.

metadata.background_info:
The Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is set to take place in Malmö, Sweden, following the country's victory at the 2023 contest. The contest will be held at the Malmö Arena, and will consist of two semi-finals on 7 and 9 May, and a final on 11 May 2024.

Of the 37 participating countries, 6 are guaranteed to participate in the final: The hosting country (Sweden) and the "Big Five" countries (United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain). The remaining 31 countries will have to compete in the Semi-finals. In each Semi-final, 10 countries will qualify for the final, and the rest will not.

More information can be found on [Wikipedia](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/21827/countries-in-eurovision-2024-final/)

See also: [How the Eurovision Song Contest works](https://eurovision.tv/about/how-it-works)

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which of these countries will qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024? (Albania)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body: This question will resolve immediately as **Yes** for countries that participate in a Semi-final and are then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. For all other countries, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Albania has participated in the Eurovision Song Contest since 2004 and has had a mixed record of qualifying for the Grand Final. Historically, their overall qualification rate is about 50%. However, in recent years, their performance has improved. Specifically, Albania qualified for the Grand Final in 2018, 2019, 2021, and 2023, only missing out in 2022 out of the last five contests (excluding 2020, which was canceled). This suggests a recent qualification rate of 80%. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Albania has not yet selected or announced their entry for Eurovision 2024. Without information about the artist or song, it's challenging to assess the quality of their potential entry. Nevertheless, given their recent positive trend in qualifications and growing experience in the competition, there is a higher likelihood that they will continue to perform well. Taking into account their improved recent track record and adjusting for the uncertainty of an unknown entry, I estimate the probability of Albania qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024 to be approximately 65%.

Looking ahead to Eurovision 2024: - As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Poland has not announced its representative or song for the 2024 contest. - The absence of specific information about the 2024 entry means that we cannot assess the potential strength or appeal of the song and performance. - The semi-final allocations and running order, which can influence qualification chances, are also unknown at this time. Considering these factors: - **Positive Indicators**:   - Recent success in qualifying for the Grand Final.   - Possible continued improvement in national selection processes. - **Uncertainties**:   - Unknown 2024 entry and its potential appeal.   - Variable competition strength in the semi-finals.   - Unpredictable factors such as staging, performance quality, and audience preferences. Based on Poland's recent track record and assuming they maintain or improve their selection strategy, there is a moderately favorable chance of qualification. However, the inherent uncertainties of the contest prevent a higher confidence level.

question.title: Will Israel carry out a deadly attack within Iran before May 1, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves **Yes** if, following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, credible reports indicate that an attack attributed to Israel and occurring within Iran's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

metadata.background_info: In a significant escalation of regional tensions, [Iran launched a coordinated aerial attack targeting Israeli territory on April 13, 2024](https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/iran-tries-to-calibrate-response-against-israel-after-deadly-bombing-abb38b57). This action by Iran came as a direct retaliation for an [Israeli airstrike earlier in the month](https://apnews.com/article/israel-syria-airstrike-iranian-embassy-edca34c52d38c8bc57281e4ebf33b240#:~:text=An%20Israeli%20airstrike%20in%20a,at%20least%20five%20Iranian%20advisers.), which struck the Iranian Embassy complex in Damascus, Syria, which resulted in the deaths of seven Iranian officers, including three high-ranking commanders, intensifying Iran's resolve to respond.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The time frame between April 13, 2024, and May 1, 2024, is approximately two and a half weeks. Israel and Iran have a history of tension and have engaged in covert operations against each other. Israel has been reported to carry out targeted assassinations and sabotage operations within Iran, particularly aimed at disrupting Iran's nuclear program. However, attacks resulting in the deaths of five or more individuals within Iran and attributed directly to Israel are relatively rare and would represent a significant escalation.

As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there were no indications of an imminent large-scale attack by Israel inside Iran that would result in such casualties. Such an operation would carry substantial risks for regional stability and could provoke significant retaliation from Iran. While the possibility cannot be entirely ruled out due to the volatile nature of the region, the likelihood of Israel conducting an attack within Iran leading to the death of at least five individuals in this short time frame is low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump testify at the hush money trial?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report Donald Trump has testified, whether in person or remotely, at the [trial](https://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/webcrim_attorney/Detail?which=case&docketNumber=q23XFOwZRDQ1d4LrNRdw2clqCMt/CzUoG/kRII/7Nmg=&countyId=K4i18rFVPQh5HTQ/kUoO3Q==&docketId=3Y4iKU5oHM75AtDme2cPhw==&docketDseq=T/O1YN_PLUS_BG65HkOeqEnpAkw==&defendantName=TRUMP,+DONALD&court=New+York+Supreme+Criminal+Court&courtType=U&recordType=U&recordNum=) concerning the so-called "hush money" payments to Stormy Daniels.

metadata.background_info:
The commencement of Donald Trump's [trial in the so-called "hush money" case](https://thehill.com/regulation/court-battles/4589001-5-things-to-know-ahead-of-trumps-hush-money-trial/) marks a historic moment as he becomes the first former U.S. president to face criminal charges in court. The trial centers around allegations that Trump, during the 2016 presidential campaign, orchestrated a hush money payment to an adult film actress to prevent damaging stories from surfacing. This payment, and similar transactions, are claimed by the Manhattan district attorney to have been unlawfully logged as legal expenses by Trump’s company.

The trial is scheduled to commence on April 15th, 2024 and is expected to last approximately six weeks.

*This question is part of the Q2 2024 Quarterly Cup, however, if the trial has not concluded when the tournament ends on July 8, 2024, it will not be scored in the Quarterly Cup. It will still count as part of the annual leaderboard.*

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Donald Trump is scheduled to stand trial in March 2024 for charges related to the hush money payments to Stormy Daniels. In criminal trials, it is common for defendants to choose not to testify in their own defense to avoid cross-examination and potential self-incrimination. Trump's legal team is likely to advise him against testifying to minimize legal risks. However, Donald Trump is known for his desire to publicly defend himself and control the narrative. His personality and public persona might incline him to want to testify. Despite this, the legal risks associated with testifying in a criminal trial are significant. Considering these factors—the legal advisability of not testifying, the common practice of defendants remaining silent, and Trump's personal tendencies—I estimate that there is a moderate but not high probability that he will testify at the trial between April 17, 2024, and June 15, 2024.

question.title: Will the governor of Gagauzia, Evghenia Guțul, travel to the Russian Federation before June 1, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, after April 24, 2024, and before June 1, 2024, credible sources report that Evghenia Guțul has traveled to Russian territory within that period.

metadata.background_info:
When it comes to separatism and Moldova, most will likely recall Transnistria, which is controlled by separatists and elements of the Russian Federation armed forces since the 1990s.

However, another autonomous region of Moldova, [Gagauzia](https://www.clingendael.org/pub/2022/walking-the-tightrope-towards-the-eu/4-gagauzia-the-restless-region-in-the-south/), is currently undergoing major "temptation" from Russia. The region, inhabited by over 120,000 Gagauzes, who are an Orthodox, mostly Russian speaking Moldovan minority, is newly connected to the Mir banking system, Russian [propaganda](https://dfrlab.org/2024/03/19/kremlin-media-blitz-gagauzia/) is widely spreading (most TV channels are Russian), and control of the [Chisinau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chi%C8%99in%C4%83u) government is openly challenged.

The most important figure in this new development is Evghenia Guțul, a young pro-Russian politician, who was [elected](https://www.rferl.org/a/gutul-gagauzia-moldova-leader-shor-party/32412419.html) a governor of the region in the last year's elections, which brought a lot of controversy due to allegations of corruption and the fact that Guțul ran on a ticket of a banned Pro-Russian party (connected to the Russian oligarch Ilan Shor).

Guțul visited Russia twice in the last several weeks. The most recent [visit](https://balkaninsight.com/2024/04/10/moldovas-restive-gagauzia-region-mulls-using-russian-payment-cards/) occurred on the 8th of April, and before that on the 6th of March, during which she [met](https://balkaninsight.com/2024/03/07/pro-moscow-governor-of-moldovas-gagauzia-seeks-putins-help/) with Russian President Vladimir Putin (edit May 6, 2024: Guțul also appears to have been in Moscow when this question was launched, with a [meeting in Moscow on April 22](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/moldova-brings-criminal-case-against-pro-russian-gagauzia-leader-court-2024-04-24/) and on [April 24](https://twitter.com/EvgheniaGutul/status/1783236723297685785)).

In the aftermath of both visits Russia promised to "protect" Gagauzia and also to distribute monthly [payments](https://cepa.org/article/the-kremlin-decides-to-buy-a-population/) to Gagauzian civil servants and senior citizens (together accounting for approximately 25,000 people).

More Guțul visits in Russia might signal rapid development in this region, which could mean further deterioration of the relationship between Gagauzia and Moldovan government.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Evghenia Guțul is the governor of Gagauzia, an autonomous region in Moldova with a predominantly pro-Russian population. She was elected in 2023 as a member of the Șor Party, which is known for its pro-Russian stance. Given her political alignment, it is plausible that she would seek to strengthen ties with the Russian Federation.

However, there are several factors to consider:

1. **Political Tensions**: Moldova's central government is pro-European and has been attempting to reduce Russian influence in the country. There have been increasing tensions between the central government and pro-Russian regions like Gagauzia.

2. **Legal Challenges**: The Șor Party and its members have faced legal challenges and investigations related to corruption. Ilan Șor, the party leader, has been convicted in absentia for his role in a major bank fraud. This could result in travel restrictions or caution on Guțul's part to avoid legal repercussions.

3. **Travel Restrictions**: The Moldovan government may impose travel bans or restrictions on officials associated with pro-Russian activities. This could prevent Guțul from legally traveling to Russia.

4. **International Relations**: Given the ongoing conflict involving Russia and Ukraine, any official visit to Russia by a Moldovan regional leader could have significant diplomatic implications. Guțul might avoid such a trip to prevent exacerbating tensions.

5. **Recent Activities**: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been no official announcements or credible reports indicating that Guțul plans to visit Russia within the specified timeframe.

Considering the above factors, while there is a possibility that Evghenia Guțul might attempt to visit Russia to reinforce her political affiliations, the legal and political obstacles make it less likely.

question.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:



- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:



- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

metadata.background_info: [Reporting suggests](https://www.politico.eu/article/russian-victory-over-ukranian-key-city-chasiv-yar-jeopardize-entire-donetsk-region/) that the Ukrainian military sees the city of Chasiv Yar as strategically significant, and that the capture of the city could jeopardize the remaining key cities in the [Donetsk oblast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donetsk_Oblast). Ukraine has [reportedly said](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/why-is-russia-trying-capture-ukrainian-town-chasiv-yar-2024-04-16/) that Russia aims to capture the city by May 9.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine remains active, particularly in the eastern regions of Ukraine. Chasiv Yar is a strategic town located near Bakhmut in the Donetsk Oblast. Earlier in 2023, Russian forces, including Wagner Group mercenaries, captured Bakhmut after intense fighting. However, Ukrainian forces have since launched counteroffensives in the area, aiming to reclaim lost territories.

Several factors influence the likelihood of Russia controlling Chasiv Yar by June 1, 2024:

1. **Ukrainian Counteroffensives**: The Ukrainian military has been making gradual progress in its counteroffensives, supported by Western-supplied weapons and training. Their focus on recapturing key locations could prevent Russian advances toward Chasiv Yar.

2. **Russian Military Capacity**: Russia has faced logistical challenges, manpower shortages, and low morale among troops. If these issues persist, they may hinder Russia's ability to capture and hold new territory.

3. **International Support**: Continued international support for Ukraine, including economic sanctions on Russia and military aid to Ukraine, may strengthen Ukraine's defensive capabilities.

4. **Winter Conditions**: The approaching winter may slow down military operations for both sides, potentially leading to a stalemate in certain areas.

5. **Political Developments**: Any negotiations or shifts in political will on either side could impact military strategies and territorial control.

Considering these factors, while it's possible that Russia could attempt to capture Chasiv Yar, the probability that they will successfully control it by the specified date is moderate but not high.

question.title: Before July 1, 2024, will the International Criminal Court issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a [warrant of arrest](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) for any of the below listed Israeli cabinet members. It will resolve as **No** otherwise.

* Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

metadata.background_info:
In April 29, 2024, Axios [reported](https://www.axios.com/2024/04/29/netanyahu-biden-icc-arrest-warrants-war-crimes) that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asked US President Joe Biden to help prevent the International Criminal Court (ICC) in The Hague from issuing arrest warrants for Israeli cabinet officials stemming from possible allegations of war crimes in Gaza. NBC [reported](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/israel-fears-icc-issue-arrest-warrants-netanyahu-gaza-war-hamas-rcna149739) that these arrest warrants could come as early as this week, and Israel is working through back channels to try to prevent them from being issued. The US and other G7 countries are [reportedly](https://www.timesofisrael.com/report-several-nations-urging-icc-not-to-issue-arrest-warrants-for-israelis/) campaigning to dissuade the ICC from issuing the warrants so as to avoid jeopardizing a peace deal between Israel and Hamas.

As the ICC [explains](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) on its official website, an arrest warrant is requested by the Prosecutor as part of the investigative stage before trial, especially in cases in which suspects do not appear voluntarily.

The ICC [was founded](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Criminal_Court) in 2002 following the wars in Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia, and it is [intended](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/04/29/icc-israel-warrants-gaza/) as a permanent court to investigate war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity done by individuals. It issued its first arrest warrants in 2005, and according to the AP [has issued](https://apnews.com/article/israel-hamas-gaza-international-criminal-court-hague-palestinians-1f683a6e2e150d91c415eb1d0a19a44d) a total of 42 arrest warrants. Last year the ICC issued arrest warrants for [Vladimir Putin](https://www.icc-cpi.int/news/situation-ukraine-icc-judges-issue-arrest-warrants-against-vladimir-vladimirovich-putin-and) and one of his government officials stemming from the ICC's investigation into the deportation of Ukrainian children to Russia.

See Also

Base rate information at Wikipedia: [International Criminal Court investigations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Criminal_Court_investigations)

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the International Criminal Court (ICC) has initiated investigations into alleged war crimes in the Palestinian territories, which could potentially involve Israeli officials. However, the ICC's processes are typically lengthy and can take several years to move from investigation to issuing arrest warrants. Israel is not a member of the ICC and disputes its jurisdiction, which adds legal and political complexities to any potential action against Israeli leaders.

Issuing arrest warrants for high-ranking officials such as the Prime Minister, Defense Minister, or IDF Chief of Staff would be unprecedented and carry significant geopolitical repercussions. The ICC has historically been cautious in pursuing sitting heads of state or top officials from countries with strong international influence. Additionally, the time frame before July 1, 2024, is relatively short for such a significant legal action to occur.

Considering these factors—the ICC's lengthy procedures, Israel's non-member status and contestation of jurisdiction, the political sensitivities, and the short time frame—it is unlikely that the ICC will issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders before the specified date.

question.title: Will the Crimean Bridge be hit with an attack before July 1, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, after May 2, 2024, and before the listed date, [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report that the Crimean Bridge has been struck with weapons fire, explosives, or projectiles that could pose a credible threat to the integrity of the bridge.

metadata.background_info:
The [Crimean Bridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_Bridge) crosses the [Kerch Strait](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerch_Strait) between the Crimean peninsula and the Russian mainland. The bridge is [approximately 12 miles long](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/may/15/putin-opens-bridge-between-crimea-and-russian-mainland) and consists of a separated four-lane road bridge and a two-track rail bridge. Since the Russian invasion of Ukraine the Crimean Bridge has been [attacked three times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_Bridge#Attacks_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine), with attacks successfully damaging the bridge in October of 2022 and July of 2023, and the third attack failing to strike the bridge in August of 2023.

In April of 2024 there were reports that Ukraine is planning another attack on the Crimean Bridge. On April 4, 2024, [The Guardian reported](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2024/apr/03/ukraine-eyes-kerch-bridge-crimea-drone-attack):

>The HUR [[Defense Intelligence of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Directorate_of_Intelligence_(Ukraine))] thinks it can disable the bridge soon. “We will do it in the first half of 2024,” one official told the Guardian, adding that Kyrylo Budanov, the head of the main directorate of intelligence, already had “most of the means to carry out this goal”. He was following a plan approved by Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, to “minimise” Russia’s naval presence in the Black Sea.

On April 26, 2024, [Newsweek reported](https://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-decoy-missiles-crimea-bridge-attack-rybar-1894639) that an attack could coincide with Russian President Vladimir Putin's [May 7 inauguration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Russian_presidential_election#:~:text=He%20is%20scheduled%20to%20be%20inaugurated%20on%207%20May%202024.):

>[Telegram channel] Rybar said an attack on the Kerch Bridge could happen before the inauguration of Putin on May 7. The Russian leader last month secured his fifth term in office.
>
>"Considering the love of the Ukrainian authorities and their curators for symbolism, the target once again may be the Crimean Bridge, the attention to which is very high," Rybar said.
>
>The analysis comes after Russian military expert Vladislav Shurygin said on state TV that he believes Ukraine will attack the Kerch Strait Bridge on May 7.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Will the Crimean Bridge be hit with an attack before the listed dates? (July 1, 2024)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, after May 2, 2024, and before the listed date, [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report that the Crimean Bridge has been struck with weapons fire, explosives, or projectiles that could pose a credible threat to the integrity of the bridge.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine remains unresolved, with ongoing military engagements in eastern Ukraine and other contested regions. The Crimean Bridge, also known as the Kerch Strait Bridge, is a vital supply route for Russia, connecting the Russian mainland with the annexed Crimean Peninsula. This bridge holds significant strategic and symbolic importance for Russia.

In October 2022, the bridge sustained damage from an explosion, which was attributed to Ukrainian forces by Russian officials, although Ukraine did not claim responsibility. This incident highlighted the bridge as a vulnerable and high-value target in the conflict.

Several factors influence the likelihood of the bridge being attacked again before July 1, 2024:

1. **Continuation of Hostilities**: If the conflict persists into mid-2024, Ukrainian forces may seek to disrupt Russian supply lines to weaken their military operations in occupied territories, making the bridge a logical target.

2. **Military Capabilities**: Ukraine has been receiving military support from Western nations, potentially enhancing their ability to conduct long-range or covert operations against strategic targets like the bridge.

3. **Russian Defenses**: Following previous attacks, Russia has likely increased security measures around the bridge, including enhanced air defenses and surveillance, which could deter or prevent successful attacks.

4. **International Influence**: Diplomatic efforts, sanctions, and international pressure could either escalate or de-escalate the conflict, affecting the probability of such attacks.

5. **Strategic Priorities**: Ukraine must balance the benefits of attacking the bridge against potential repercussions, such as escalation of conflict or civilian casualties.

Given these considerations, there is a moderate likelihood that the bridge could be targeted within the specified timeframe. The uncertainty stems from the unpredictable nature of the conflict's progression, the effectiveness of Russian defensive measures, and the evolving military strategies of the involved parties.

question.title: Will UCLA hold its in-person, university-wide graduation commencement ceremonies scheduled for June 14, 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the University of California-Los Angeles (UCLA) holds all three of its main in-person college commencement ceremonies for the graduating Class of 2024 [scheduled](https://commencement.ucla.edu/schedule/ucla-commencement-schedule-alphabetical#college) for the following times and locations on June 14, 2024:

- 11 AM at the Pauley Pavilion
- 3 PM at the Pauley Pavilion
- 7 PM at the Pauley Pavilion

The ceremonies must all occur at the specified locations and begin within 1 hour of the scheduled starting time. 

This question will resolve as **No** if any ceremony either does not begin within an hour of the scheduled time, is moved to another location, or is held entirely online (i.e., without graduates, faculty, and guests attending in person).

metadata.background_info:
On May 6, 2024, Columbia University [cancelled](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2024/05/06/columbia-commencement-ceremony-protest-live-updates/73583447007/) its main commencement ceremony, opting instead to honor its graduates in 19 smaller ceremonies for each of its colleges. The decision was made in response to pro-Palestinian protests that erupted at the university. 

UCLA has [cancelled in-person classes](https://www.cbsnews.com/losangeles/news/ucla-cancel-in-person-classes-again-after-more-israel-hamas-war-protests/) at its campus, and there has been speculation that it may cancel its main commencement as well. Its fellow southern California school, USC, recently [moved its ceremony](https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2024-05-03/usc-shores-up-campus-limits-access-before-commencement) to the LA Coliseum.

See Also: 

MSN: [Pro-Palestinian Protests Put College Commencements in Jeopardy](https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/pro-palestinian-protests-put-college-commencements-in-jeopardy/ar-BB1lUU4h)

Newsweek: [Full List of Colleges Cancelling Graduation Services Amid Campus Protests](https://www.newsweek.com/columbia-cancels-graduation-ceremony-universities-palestine-protests-1897560)

USA Today: [College graduation canceled due to anti-war protests? It's happened before](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/education/2024/05/07/why-do-colleges-cancel-graduation-a-brief-history/73586349007/)

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, there are no indications that UCLA will not hold its in-person, university-wide graduation commencement ceremonies scheduled for June 14, 2024, at the Pauley Pavilion at the specified times. Historically, UCLA has consistently conducted its commencement ceremonies as planned, except during extraordinary circumstances such as the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, which led to virtual ceremonies. Currently, there are no known factors—such as public health emergencies, significant construction projects at the venue, or other major disruptions—that would prevent the ceremonies from occurring as scheduled. While unforeseen events like natural disasters or unexpected crises can occur, they are relatively rare. Therefore, it is highly likely that UCLA will hold its in-person commencement ceremonies as planned.

question.title: Will the Pandemic Agreement be approved at the May 2024 World Health Assembly?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, during the May 2024 World Health Assembly (WHA) the Pandemic Agreement is approved in a vote, according to reports from credible sources.

metadata.background_info:
In late 2021 member states of the World Health Organization (WHO) [began negotiating an international agreement on pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response](https://www.kff.org/global-health-policy/issue-brief/the-pandemic-agreement-what-it-is-what-it-isnt-and-what-it-could-mean-for-the-u-s), which has been known as the Pandemic Agreement or Pandemic Accord. The [goal of the agreement](https://www.who.int/news/item/01-12-2021-world-health-assembly-agrees-to-launch-process-to-develop-historic-global-accord-on-pandemic-prevention-preparedness-and-response) is to improve responsiveness to better combat future pandemics using lessons learned from the COVID-19 response.

A [round of negotiations](https://www.who.int/news/item/28-03-2024-who-member-states-agree-to-resume-negotiations-aimed-at-finalizing-the-world-s-first-pandemic-agreement) aimed at finalizing the agreement began on April 29, 2024, and are scheduled to end on May 10, 2024. The agreement is [scheduled to be considered for adoption](https://www.who.int/news/item/28-03-2024-who-member-states-agree-to-resume-negotiations-aimed-at-finalizing-the-world-s-first-pandemic-agreement) at the upcoming [Seventy-seventh World Health Assembly](https://www.who.int/about/accountability/governance/world-health-assembly/seventy-seventh) taking place May 27 to June 1, 2024.

The level of agreement needed to approve the Pandemic Agreement may depend on the final form of the agreement, [such as whether it would be considered a treaty, regulation, or resolution](https://www.kff.org/global-health-policy/issue-brief/the-pandemic-agreement-what-it-is-what-it-isnt-and-what-it-could-mean-for-the-u-s/#:~:text=What%20are%20possible%20outcomes%20of%20the%20agreement%20negotiations%3F). Politicians in some WHO member countries, including the United States, [have stated opposition](https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/who-chief-urges-countries-finalise-pandemic-accord-by-deadline-2024-05-03/) to the agreement on the basis of potentially being subject to legally binding rules within the agreement.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the World Health Organization (WHO) has been actively working on a new international instrument, often referred to as the "Pandemic Agreement" or "Pandemic Treaty." This agreement aims to strengthen global coordination and response to future pandemics, drawing lessons from the COVID-19 pandemic. Several factors influence the likelihood of the Pandemic Agreement being approved at the May 2024 World Health Assembly (WHA): 1. Negotiation Progress: The Intergovernmental Negotiating Body (INB) has been holding sessions to draft and negotiate the agreement's terms. Progress reports suggest that while there is general consensus on the need for such an agreement, key provisions are still under negotiation. 2. Member States' Positions: Some member states have differing views on critical issues such as equity in access to vaccines and treatments, intellectual property rights, data sharing, and the balance between national sovereignty and international obligations. Resolving these differences is crucial for approval. 3. Geopolitical Tensions: Ongoing geopolitical tensions, especially between major powers, could hinder consensus. Disagreements on unrelated international issues might spill over into WHO negotiations. 4. Historical Precedents: Historically, international agreements of this magnitude (e.g., the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control) have taken several years to negotiate and ratify. Completing the process by May 2024 would be ambitious. 5. Urgency and Political Will: The recent memory of the COVID-19 pandemic creates a sense of urgency.
