However, as of June 30, 2024, prominent Democrats continued to publicly stand behind Biden, such as former President [Barack Obama](https://www.axios.com/2024/06/28/obama-rescue-biden-calm-nervous-democrats-2024-election) and Congressman [James E. Clyburn](https://thehill.com/homenews/house/4746240-clyburn-biden-debate/). Initial polling after the debate [found](https://www.forbes.com/sites/brianbushard/2024/06/29/warning-signs-for-biden-post-debate-polls-show-more-voters-worried-about-bidens-fitness-but-race-still-virtually-tied/) that increasing numbers of voters believe Biden should drop out. On June 26, 2024 , the day before the debate, Biden was behind Trump by 0.1 in the [538 polling averages](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/). On June 30th, following several post-debate polls, Biden's deficit swelled to 1.3 points. See Also Pew Research: [Contested presidential conventions, and why parties try to avoid them](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2016/02/04/contested-presidential-conventions-and-why-parties-try-to-avoid-them/)
US News & World Report: [What Is an Open Convention and Why Do Some Democrats Want One?](https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2024-06-28/what-is-an-open-convention-and-why-do-some-democrats-want-one)
Wikipedia: [Brokered convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brokered_convention)
The Atlantic: [The Biden-Replacement Operation](https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2024/06/great-democratic-conundrum-biden/678830/)

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden is the incumbent president and has announced his intention to seek re-election in the 2024 presidential race. Incumbent presidents who run for re-election typically face minimal opposition within their own party, and it is uncommon for a serious challenger to unseat them during the primary process.

While there are a few individuals who have announced intentions to run against President Biden in the Democratic primaries—such as Marianne Williamson and Robert F. Kennedy Jr.—these candidates have not secured significant support within the party establishment or among primary voters. They are generally considered long-shot candidates with low chances of winning a substantial number of delegates.

Historically, brokered conventions are rare in modern U.S. politics. The last time a major party convention required more than one ballot to nominate a presidential candidate was in 1952 for the Democrats. Since then, the primary system has been structured to produce a clear nominee before the convention through pledged delegates won in primaries and caucuses.

The Democratic Party also employs superdelegates (now officially called "automatic delegates"), but changes in party rules after the 2016 election have reduced their influence on the first ballot. In the 2020 election cycle, automatic delegates were prohibited from voting on the first ballot unless the outcome was already decided by pledged delegates.

Given President Biden's incumbent status, the lack of strong challengers, and the historical rarity of brokered conventions, it is highly unlikely that the Democratic Party will require more than one round of voting at the 2024 convention to nominate its presidential candidate.

question.title: Will the US government end its agreement directly allowing Verisign to manage the authoritative domain name registry for the .com TLD, before August 3, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if before August 3, 2024, the US Department of Commerce (DOC) officially terminates or sunsets its Cooperative Agreement with Verisign recognizing Verisign's management of the *.com* generic top-level domain (TLD). If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.background_info:
[Verisign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verisign) operates the authoritative registry for the .com generic top-level domain (TLD) under a registry agreement with the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) and a [Cooperative Agreement](https://www.ntia.gov/page/verisign-cooperative-agreement) with the US Department of Commerce (DOC). This means it is the wholesale provider of the .com TLD to every domain name registrar. The American Economic Liberties Projected [has called](https://www.economicliberties.us/press-release/ntia-and-doj-must-break-verisigns-monopoly-power-over-domain-names-advocates-urge/) this arrangement a "government-designated monopoly over domain registration." According to [The American Prospect](https://prospect.org/power/2024-06-27-government-created-most-profitable-company-verisign/):

>You have probably never heard of the most profitable company in America, and possibly the world. It’s a government-granted monopoly that feasts on high margins for a low-dollar administrative product. Today, three advocacy groups pressured the Biden administration to take down the rules in place that enable this gravy train.

>The company is called VeriSign [*sic*], and it has exclusive control of the registration system for the .com domain name. Every year, hundreds of millions of website owners pay VeriSign [*sic*] a small annual fee to keep their .com in working order. Every year, the cost of managing the database to make sure that .com websites work either stays flat or goes down, while the fee for registering a .com website goes up.

The Cooperative Agreement between Verisign and the US DOC will automatically renew for a six-year term unless the DOC provides notice of non-renewal on August 2, 2024.

According to [Bloomberg](https://archive.ph/IXZ3V#selection-1705.0-1726.0), during the 2018 renewal the Trump Administration lifted the cap on wholesale prices for *.com*. The antitrust advocacy groups have written to the Justice Department to withdraw guidance that allowed the elimination of price caps in the 2018 renewal, with the letters citing President Biden’s 2021 [executive order](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/07/09/executive-order-on-promoting-competition-in-the-american-economy/) on competition.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Verisign has been managing the .com top-level domain (TLD) under a Cooperative Agreement with the U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC) since 1999. This agreement is crucial for the stability and functioning of the internet, as .com is the most widely used TLD globally. There have been no public indications, announcements, or policy moves suggesting that the DOC intends to terminate or sunset this agreement with Verisign.

Ending such a significant agreement would likely involve extensive planning, stakeholder consultations, and public announcements well in advance. It would also require coordination with international organizations like the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN). Given the complexity and the potential impact on global internet infrastructure, any move to terminate the agreement would likely be a protracted process with considerable notice.

Based on the lack of any indications of impending termination and the importance of the agreement to internet stability, it is unlikely that the U.S. government will end its agreement with Verisign before August 3, 2024.

question.title: Will the domestic box office opening of "Deadpool & Wolverine" be higher than that of "Deadpool" and "The Wolverine" combined?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the domestic box office opening for the **Deadpool & Wolverine** reported by Boxofficemojo on the [movie's page](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/title/tt6263850/?ref_=bo_se_r_1) is higher than $185,548,391 which is the sum of the box openings for **Deadpool** (2016) and **The Wolverine** (2013): $132,434,639 + $53,113,752.

metadata.background_info:
**Deadpool & Wolverine** is an upcoming blockbuster by Marvel Studios scheduled to be released on July 26, 2024 featuring the two iconic heroes from the X-Men Universe.

The recent projection from Deadline puts the domestic opening to [$160-$165 million](https://deadline.com/2024/07/deadpool-wolverine-box-office-opening-projection-1236000799/), which would not only be the best opening year-to-date (beating **Inside Out 2** with $154 million) but also a record start for an R-rated movie. 

Another projection from June was even higher, [at $200+ million](https://deadline.com/2024/06/deadpool-wolverine-box-office-projection-1235973545/).

The ticket seller Fandango [reported on May 21](https://www.gamespot.com/articles/deadpool-and-wolverine-has-strongest-day-one-ticket-pre-sales-in-franchise-history-at-fandango/1100-6523599/) that their ticket pre-sales for the movie were the site's biggest ones in 2024 up to date.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, "Deadpool 3" is scheduled for release on May 3, 2024, featuring both Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) and Wolverine (Hugh Jackman). The original "Deadpool" (2016) had a domestic opening weekend of approximately $132 million, while "The Wolverine" (2013) opened at around $53 million, combining for a total of $185 million. To surpass $185,548,391 in its domestic opening, "Deadpool 3" would need to achieve one of the highest opening weekends in box office history. Only a select few films have crossed this threshold, such as "Avengers: Endgame" and "Star Wars: The Force Awakens." While the return of Hugh Jackman as Wolverine alongside Ryan Reynolds' Deadpool is highly anticipated and could boost ticket sales, it's uncertain if it will generate such a record-breaking opening. Considering the strong fan bases and the excitement surrounding the film, it's possible but not highly likely that "Deadpool 3" will exceed the combined opening of its predecessors.

question.title: On July 17, 2024, will Nvidia's market capitalization be larger than Apple's?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if, on July 17, 2024, the market cap of Nvidia is greater than that of Apple, according to Companies Market Cap, when checked by Metaculus at approximately 4 PM EDT (8 PM UTC).

metadata.background_info:
Since late 2022, Nvidia Corporation has experienced nearly 10x growth in market capitalization, driven by its [dominance in the AI chip market](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/nvidias-ai-chip-dominance-continue-210200974.html). Nvidia's GPUs are critical in the development of large language models, and are highly sought after by major tech companies like OpenAI, Microsoft, Amazon, and Alphabet.

On May 22nd, Nvidia released [impressive Q1 financial results](https://nvidianews.nvidia.com/news/nvidia-announces-financial-results-for-first-quarter-fiscal-2025#:~:text=NVIDIA%20(NASDAQ%3A%20NVDA)%20today,262%25%20from%20a%20year%20ago.) and simultaneously announced a 10:1 stock split and increase to its dividend, sending its stock price to new all-time highs.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: As of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, Apple Inc. had a market capitalization significantly higher than that of Nvidia Corporation. However, for an updated analysis as of October 2023: - **Apple Inc. Market Capitalization**: Apple remains one of the most valuable companies globally, with a market cap around $2.5 trillion. The company has a diverse product lineup, including iPhones, iPads, Macs, wearables, and services. Apple's strong brand loyalty, consistent revenue streams, and expansion into services contribute to its robust financial position. - **Nvidia Corporation Market Capitalization**: Nvidia has experienced substantial growth due to its leadership in graphics processing units (GPUs) and its pivotal role in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning sectors. As of October 2023, Nvidia's market cap is approximately $1 trillion. The surge in demand for AI applications and data center technologies has bolstered Nvidia's market position. **Factors to Consider**: 1. **Growth Potential for Nvidia**: - **AI and Machine Learning Demand**: If the demand for AI technology continues to grow exponentially, Nvidia could see significant revenue increases. - **Product Innovation**: Breakthroughs in GPU technology or new product lines could further enhance Nvidia's market position. - **Market Expansion**: Entry into new markets or successful acquisitions could propel growth. 2. **Apple's Market Dynamics**: - **Product Saturation**: The smartphone market is highly saturated; significant growth may be challenging. - **Innovation Pace**: Without groundbreaking new products, Apple's growth may slow. - **Regulatory Challenges**: Antitrust regulations or supply chain issues could impact Apple's performance. 3. **Economic Conditions**: - **Market Volatility**: Economic downturns could affect tech stocks differently. - **Investor Sentiment**: Shifts in investment trends towards AI could favor Nvidia. **Assessment**: - **Likelihood of Nvidia Surpassing Apple**: For Nvidia's market cap to exceed Apple's by July 17, 2024, Nvidia would need to more than double its market cap (assuming Apple's remains stable), which is a substantial increase in less than a year. - **Apple's Stability**: Apple's diversified portfolio and strong financials make a significant decline in market cap less likely in the short term. - **Potential Scenarios**: While it's possible that Nvidia continues its rapid growth trajectory, surpassing Apple would require exceptional circumstances, such as revolutionary advancements or significant market shifts. **Conclusion**: Given the current information and market trends, while Nvidia is positioned for growth, the probability of it surpassing Apple's market capitalization by July 17, 2024, is relatively low but not negligible.

question.title:
Will the  CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index (VXVCLS)	
 be higher Year-over-Year on July 20, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve based on reporting by the St. Louis Fed here: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/VXVCLS. The reported number for July 20, 2024 must be greater than the reported number on July 20, 2023.

metadata.background_info: According to [FRED](https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/VXVCLS): > Chicago Board Options Exchange, CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index [VXVCLS], retrieved from FRED, Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index (VXVCLS) measures the market's expectation of volatility over the next three months for the S&P 500 index. Volatility indices like the VXVCLS are known to be mean-reverting—they tend to return to their long-term average over time.

Historically, volatility remains low during stable economic periods and spikes during times of market stress or uncertainty, such as financial crises, geopolitical tensions, or significant economic policy changes. Since volatility spends more time at lower levels and experiences sharp increases only occasionally, the probability that the VXVCLS will be higher on a specific future date compared to the same date a year prior is less than 50%.

Over the course of a year, there is always the possibility of unforeseen events that could increase market volatility. Factors such as changes in interest rates, inflation concerns, political elections, or global economic shifts can impact investor sentiment and market stability. However, without a specific catalyst expected to cause increased volatility on July 20, 2024, it is more likely that the VXVCLS will be at or below its level from July 20, 2023.

Taking into account the mean-reverting nature of volatility, the tendency for volatility to remain low absent significant market disturbances, and the unpredictability of potential future events, I estimate the probability that the VXVCLS will be higher on July 20, 2024, compared to July 20, 2023, to be approximately 40%.

question.title: Will the Prime Minister of France belong to the Together coalition on July 30, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if the party of the Prime Minister of France is Together on July 30th, at 12:00 Central European Time, according to credible sources.

metadata.background_info:
After a far-right victory in the European elections, French President Emmanuel Macron dissolved the National Assembly, calling snap elections for June 30th and July 7th.

The majority of the 577 districts will [see a runoff](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/french-election-run-off-how-does-it-work-what-look-out-2024-07-05/) on Sunday, July 7, with the most common set of qualified parties being the National Rally-led Union of the Far-Right, centrist Together, and left and center-left New Popular Front. The unprecedented number of three-way runoffs (including *four*-ways in five districts) was boosted by strong turnout, [nearly 20 percentage points more than in 2022](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/strong-turnout-france-high-stakes-elections-support-far-right-grows/); but Together and the NPF guided their third-placed candidates to withdraw to improve the other's chances to beat the far-right, mostly represented by Marine Le Pen's National Rally.

Once the runoff numbers are known for the 17th National Assembly, the question becomes: who will be Prime Minister? The French semi-presidential system gives President Macron political responsibilities, in particular in foreign policy, regardless of the makeup of Parliament; but he must also nominate a Prime Minister, who conducts domestic policy. The government does not need a positive confidence vote from legislators, but it could be subject to a vote of no confidence; current Prime Minister Gabriel Attal's minority government has been relying on case-by-case deals to get legislation approved.

While the far-right has already elected 38 Deputies and made it to the runoff almost everywhere, its surge might still be forestalled by the strategic pact between the center and the left.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the Prime Minister of France is Élisabeth Borne, who is a member of the Together (Ensemble) coalition led by President Emmanuel Macron. The next legislative elections in France are scheduled for 2027, and there are no planned national elections before July 30, 2024, that would likely change the composition of the government.

While unexpected political events can occur—such as votes of no confidence, political scandals, or significant shifts in public opinion leading to government reshuffles—there are no strong indications that such events are imminent. The Together coalition holds a relative majority in the National Assembly, and despite facing challenges like pension reforms and public protests, it has managed to maintain its governing position.

Given the stability of the current government and the lack of scheduled elections or major upheavals on the horizon, it is likely that the Prime Minister will continue to belong to the Together coalition on July 30, 2024.

question.title: Will the Prime Minister of France belong to a coalition other than New Popular Front or Together on July 30, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if the party of the Prime Minister of France is not New Popular Front or Together on July 30th, at 12:00 Central European Time, according to credible sources.

metadata.background_info:
After a far-right victory in the European elections, French President Emmanuel Macron dissolved the National Assembly, calling snap elections for June 30th and July 7th.

The majority of the 577 districts will [see a runoff](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/french-election-run-off-how-does-it-work-what-look-out-2024-07-05/) on Sunday, July 7, with the most common set of qualified parties being the National Rally-led Union of the Far-Right, centrist Together, and left and center-left New Popular Front. The unprecedented number of three-way runoffs (including *four*-ways in five districts) was boosted by strong turnout, [nearly 20 percentage points more than in 2022](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/strong-turnout-france-high-stakes-elections-support-far-right-grows/); but Together and the NPF guided their third-placed candidates to withdraw to improve the other's chances to beat the far-right, mostly represented by Marine Le Pen's National Rally.

Once the runoff numbers are known for the 17th National Assembly, the question becomes: who will be Prime Minister? The French semi-presidential system gives President Macron political responsibilities, in particular in foreign policy, regardless of the makeup of Parliament; but he must also nominate a Prime Minister, who conducts domestic policy. The government does not need a positive confidence vote from legislators, but it could be subject to a vote of no confidence; current Prime Minister Gabriel Attal's minority government has been relying on case-by-case deals to get legislation approved.

While the far-right has already elected 38 Deputies and made it to the runoff almost everywhere, its surge might still be forestalled by the strategic pact between the center and the left.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the Prime Minister of France is Élisabeth Borne, who is a member of the coalition "Ensemble" ("Together"), which supports President Emmanuel Macron's centrist party, Renaissance (formerly La République En Marche!). The "New Popular Front" likely refers to the left-wing coalition known as the Nouvelle Union Populaire Écologique et Sociale (NUPES), which includes parties like La France Insoumise, the Socialist Party, the Communist Party, and others.

For the Prime Minister to belong to a coalition other than Together or the New Popular Front by July 30, 2024, several political shifts would need to occur:

1. **Government Resignation or Vote of No Confidence:** The current government could face a crisis leading to its resignation or a successful vote of no confidence. While political tensions exist, there have been no significant indicators of such an imminent event as of October 2023.

2. **Formation of a New Coalition:** A new coalition could form, possibly including parties not currently part of Together or NUPES, such as the right-wing National Rally (Rassemblement National) or other centrist/right-wing parties like The Republicans (Les Républicains). However, forming a government requires a majority in the National Assembly, which may be challenging without significant shifts in public opinion or defections from existing coalitions.

3. **Early Legislative Elections:** Triggering early elections could reshape the National Assembly's composition. This is relatively rare and would likely require a major political crisis.

Given the stability of the current government and the lack of indications of a significant political upheaval before July 2024, it seems unlikely that the Prime Minister will belong to a different coalition by that date. While French politics can be unpredictable, major shifts typically require more substantial lead time and visible catalysts.

question.title: Will Tadej Pogačar win the Tour de France 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve based on the cyclist who is officially recognized as the winner of the Tour de France 2024, based on official results published on the Tour de France [website](https://www.letour.fr/en/) or other [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.background_info:
The [Tour de France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Tour_de_France) is an annual men's multiple stage bicycle race primarily held in France, while also occasionally passing through nearby countries. It is the most prestigious and most difficult bicycle race in the world. The [2024 edition of the race](https://www.letour.fr/en/overall-route) started on June 29 in Florence, Italy, and will end in Nice, France on July 21.

Historical data, current form, and team support should be considered when making a prediction. Please note  also that unexpected events, such as accidents or disqualifications, may affect the outcome of the race.

For more information please see:

[New York Times What to Know About This Year’s Tour de France (Which Begins in Italy)](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/27/sports/cycling/tour-de-france-preview.html)

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Tadej Pogačar is one of the foremost cyclists in the world. He won the Tour de France in 2020 and 2021, showcasing exceptional climbing prowess and time-trial abilities. In the 2022 and 2023 editions, he finished second to Jonas Vingegaard, indicating a strong rivalry at the pinnacle of the sport.

Performance and Form:
Pogačar has consistently demonstrated his talent and resilience. At a young age, he has already secured multiple Grand Tour victories and has shown the capacity for further growth. His performance in one-day races and other stage races remains impressive, suggesting that he maintains top form.

Main Rivals:
- Jonas Vingegaard: Having won the Tour de France in 2022 and 2023, Vingegaard is a significant competitor. His climbing ability matches that of Pogačar, and their head-to-head battles have been closely contested.
- Primož Roglič: Another strong contender, though his focus may vary between Grand Tours.
- Egan Bernal: Winner of the 2019 Tour, though his form has been affected by injuries.
- Emerging talents and other experienced riders could also pose challenges, but none have consistently matched Pogačar's performance.

Team Dynamics:
Pogačar rides for UAE Team Emirates, which has been strengthening its roster to support his Tour de France ambitions. Strong team support is crucial in the Tour for protecting the leader, pacing in mountain stages, and controlling the peloton.

Uncertainties and Variables:
- Injuries and Illness: Cycling is unpredictable; crashes or health issues can impact performance.
- Team Strategy: Decisions during the race can affect outcomes, including how teams react to breakaways or collaborate.
- Course Profile: The specific route of the 2024 Tour could favor certain riders over others, depending on the balance of time trials versus mountain stages.

Assessment:
While Pogačar is undoubtedly one of the top favorites for the 2024 Tour de France, the competition from Vingegaard and others cannot be underestimated. The probability is influenced by his demonstrated ability to win, balanced against the strength of his rivals and the inherent uncertainties of the sport.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Tadej Pogačar and Jonas Vingegaard have been the dominant forces in the Tour de France over the past few years. Pogačar won the Tour in 2020 and 2021, while Vingegaard secured victories in 2022 and 2023. Both riders have demonstrated exceptional climbing abilities, time-trial skills, and resilience, making them the clear favorites for the 2024 edition.

However, several factors could lead to someone else winning the Tour de France in 2024:

1. Emerging Competitors: 
   - Remco Evenepoel: The young Belgian cyclist has shown tremendous potential, winning the 2022 Vuelta a España and excelling in one-day races and time trials. If he targets the Tour in 2024, he could be a serious contender.
   - Primož Roglič: Although his performances in the Tour have been mixed, he's a proven Grand Tour winner with victories in the Giro d'Italia and Vuelta a España.
   - Egan Bernal: The 2019 Tour de France winner has been recovering from injuries. If he returns to form, he could challenge for the title.
   - Other Contenders: Riders like Jai Hindley, Simon Yates, and Enric Mas have shown capabilities in Grand Tours and might step up.

2. Team Dynamics: Changes in team strategies, support riders, or transfers can affect race outcomes. For instance, if key domestiques switch teams, it might weaken the support for Pogačar or Vingegaard.

3. Injuries and Illness: Cycling is unpredictable; crashes or health issues can take favorites out of contention, as seen in past Tours.

4. Course Profile: The specific route of the 2024 Tour might favor different types of riders. A route with fewer climbs or more time-trial kilometers could advantage other competitors.

5. Motivation and Form: Maintaining peak performance year after year is challenging. There might be a decline in form, or other riders might peak at the right time.

Considering the dominance of Pogačar and Vingegaard but acknowledging the factors above, there's a significant chance that another cyclist could win the Tour de France in 2024.

question.title: Will Kalenjin athletes win both the men's and women's marathon races at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if both the winner of the men's and winner's marathon at the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris have Kalenjin roots, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.background_info:
The Kalenjin people, native to Kenya, [dominate racing in distances between 800m and the marathon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalenjin_people#Sport).  It is estimated that 40% of the top honours available to men in international athletics at these distances (Olympic medals, World Championships medals, and World Cross Country Championships honours) have been earned by Kalenjin runners, in spite of the ethnicity representing less than 0.1% of the human population.

Will they win both the men's and women's marathon at the 2024 Paris Olympics?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning:
The Kalenjin people of Kenya are renowned for their dominance in long-distance running, particularly in marathons. Historically, many of the top marathon runners in the world have been Kalenjin athletes.

**Men's Marathon:**
- **Eliud Kipchoge**, a Kalenjin athlete, is considered one of the greatest marathon runners of all time. He won gold in the men's marathon at both the 2016 Rio Olympics and the 2020 Tokyo Olympics (held in 2021 due to the pandemic).
- Other prominent Kalenjin male runners include Lawrence Cherono and Amos Kipruto, who have strong international standings.
- The likelihood of a Kalenjin athlete winning the men's marathon is high if they are selected to represent Kenya.

**Women's Marathon:**
- The women's field is also strong but slightly more competitive with athletes from Ethiopia and other nations.
- Notable Kalenjin female marathoners include **Brigid Kosgei** (world record holder) and **Peres Jepchirchir**, both of whom have won major international marathons.
- The competition from Ethiopian runners like Letesenbet Gidey and athletes from other countries adds uncertainty.

**Factors to Consider:**
- **Selection:** Kenya's selection process is competitive, and only the top athletes will be chosen to represent the country.
- **Injuries and Form:** Athletes' performance can be affected by injuries or changes in form leading up to the Olympics.
- **Competition:** Strong contenders from Ethiopia and other countries can impact the outcomes.

**Probability Calculation:**
- **Men's Marathon Win by Kalenjin Athlete:** Approximately 70% chance.
- **Women's Marathon Win by Kalenjin Athlete:** Approximately 60% chance.
- **Combined Probability:** 0.70 * 0.60 = 0.42 or 42%

question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time break the Olympic record of 9.63s?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete runs the Men's 100M race at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics in less than 9.63s, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.background_info:
The [100m dash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_metres) is one of the highlights of track and field events, with the world champion often referred to as "the world's fastest man".

The [current Olympic record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men%27s_100_metres_world_record_progression) was set by Jamaican sprinter Usain Bolt's at the 2012 London Olympics. Will it be broken in Paris 2024?

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Olympic record for the men's 100m dash is 9.63 seconds, set by Usain Bolt at the 2012 London Olympics. Since then, no athlete has surpassed this time during Olympic competition. At the 2016 Rio Olympics, Bolt won with a time of 9.81 seconds, and at the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy took gold with a time of 9.80 seconds. In recent years, no sprinter has consistently approached the 9.63-second mark. The current top athletes, such as Fred Kerley, Trayvon Bromell, and Andre De Grasse, have personal bests that are close but not below the Olympic record. Additionally, the world record of 9.58 seconds, also held by Usain Bolt, has remained unchallenged since 2009. Factors that could influence a record-breaking performance include advancements in training techniques, favorable weather conditions, and technological improvements in track surfaces and footwear. However, breaking an Olympic record requires an exceptional performance that aligns with these factors. Considering the historical data and recent performances, it is unlikely but not impossible that the Olympic record will be broken at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

question.title: Will the Olympic record for the men's pole vault be broken at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if at the 2024 Paris Olympics, any men's pole vault athlete clears the bar at 6.04m or higher, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.background_info:
Brazilian pole vaulter Thiago Braz set the Olympic record for the men's pole vault at 6.03m at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics. Since then, the world record [has risen to 6.24m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men%27s_pole_vault_world_record_progression), set by Swedish athlete Armand Duplantis earlier in 2024. In 2020, his only chance so far to break the Olympic record, the Swede did succeed at his 6.19m WR attempt, though he had already won gold with 6.02m.

With Braz suspended from the current Games on account of doping, will his record be broken by the dominant world record holder, or maybe by another competitor?

The men's pole vault [is scheduled](https://olympics.com/en/paris-2024/schedule/athletics/men-s-pole-vault?day=3-august) to begin August 3, 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the current Olympic record for the men's pole vault is 6.03 meters, set by Renaud Lavillenie of France at the 2012 London Olympics. The world record, however, has been significantly improved by Armand "Mondo" Duplantis of Sweden. In September 2023, Duplantis set a new world record by clearing 6.23 meters at the Diamond League Finals in Eugene, Oregon.

Duplantis has been consistently clearing heights above 6.00 meters in major competitions and has broken the world record multiple times over the past few years. His performance trajectory indicates that he is capable of surpassing the Olympic record by a substantial margin. Given that the Olympic record is considerably lower than his personal best, it is highly likely that he will break the Olympic record at the 2024 Paris Olympics, provided he remains in good health and form.

Other athletes in the field have not been clearing heights close to Duplantis's marks, so the likelihood of someone else breaking the record is low but not impossible. Factors such as weather conditions, injury, or unexpected events could impact performance, but these are relatively minor considerations given Duplantis's dominance in the event.

question.title: Will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question resolves as **No** if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in these eight team sports at the 2024 Paris Olympics: 

- association football 
- 3×3 basketball
- 5×5 basketball
- field hockey
- handball 
- rugby sevens
- volleyball
- water polo.

Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as **Yes**.

The question can resolve as soon as it becomes clear one of these conditions will happen (e.g. neither team playing the final of the last event has won any of the others).

metadata.background_info:
Although most events in the Summer Olympics are contested by individual athletes, or small teams of 2-4, a few have one single larger team representing their entire country. [These are](https://olympics.com/en/paris-2024/information/team-sports-how-can-your-team-qualify-for-the-paris-2024-olympics):

* Association football
* Basketball 5×5
* Basketball 3×3
* Field hockey
* Handball
* Rugby sevens
* Volleyball
* Water polo

(Beach volleyball is listed on the source but excluded from the question because two teams from each nation can qualify, unlike the other sports.)

Will the women's teams of the same nation win at least two of these sports? The

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the likelihood that the same nation will win more than one of the listed women's team sports at the 2024 Paris Olympics, we'll analyze the top contenders in each sport and assess overlap between nations strong in multiple sports. 1. **Association Football (Soccer)**: - **Top Contenders**: USA, Sweden, Germany, Netherlands, Canada, Brazil, England (competes as Great Britain in the Olympics), Japan. - The USA has been historically dominant but faced challenges in recent tournaments. - **USA's Chance of Winning**: Moderate (approximately 30%). 2. **3×3 Basketball**: - **Top Contenders**: USA, France, China, Russia (status may be affected by international sanctions), Mongolia. - As a newer Olympic sport, results can be unpredictable. - **USA's Chance of Winning**: Good (around 50%). 3. **5×5 Basketball**: - **Top Contenders**: USA, Australia, Spain, France, Belgium. - The USA has a strong track record, having won multiple consecutive gold medals. - **USA's Chance of Winning**: Very High (around 90%). 4. **Field Hockey**: - **Top Contenders**: Netherlands, Argentina, Germany, Australia, Great Britain. - The Netherlands is the dominant force. - **Overlap with Other Sports**: Limited. 5. **Handball**: - **Top Contenders**: Norway, France, Russia, Netherlands, Spain. - France, as the host nation, may have an advantage. - **France's Chance of Winning**: Significant (around 30%). 6. **Rugby Sevens**: - **Top Contenders**: New Zealand, Australia, Canada, France, USA. - New Zealand and Australia are strong, but France and USA are competitive. - **USA's Chance of Winning**: Moderate (approximately 25%). - **France's Chance of Winning**: Moderate (approximately 25%). 7. **Volleyball**: - **Top Contenders**: USA, Brazil, China, Serbia, Italy. - USA won gold in Tokyo 2020 and remains a top team. - **USA's Chance of Winning**: High (around 40%). 8. **Water Polo**: - **Top Contenders**: USA, Spain, Italy, Hungary, Australia. - The USA women's team has been dominant in recent years. - **USA's Chance of Winning**: Very High (around 80%). **Analysis of Overlapping Strengths**: - **USA**: - **High Probability of Gold**: 5×5 Basketball, Water Polo. - **Moderate to High Chances**: Volleyball, 3×3 Basketball, Soccer, Rugby Sevens. - **Combined Probability**: - The likelihood of the USA winning both 5×5 Basketball and Water Polo is 0.9 * 0.8 = 0.72 or 72%. - When considering chances in Volleyball and other sports, the probability increases that the USA will secure at least two gold medals. - **France**: - **Potential Strong Performances**: Handball, 3×3 Basketball, Rugby Sevens. - **Host Advantage**: Being the host nation may boost their performance. - **Combined Probability**: - While France is competitive, the chances of winning multiple golds are lower than the USA's. - **Other Nations**: - **Netherlands**: Strong in Field Hockey but less so in other listed sports. - **Australia** and **New Zealand**: Strong contenders in Rugby Sevens and competitive in others but less overlap. **Conclusion**: Given the USA's strong likelihood of winning gold medals in multiple women's team sports—especially in 5×5 Basketball and Water Polo—the probability that the same nation will win more than one of these events is high. Other nations have chances, but none have as many strong opportunities as the USA.

question.title: Will an athlete win more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

metadata.background_info: [Tennis at the Olympics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2024_Summer_Olympics) has five events: singles for men and women, and doubles for men, women and mixed. This makes it possible for the same athlete to win more than one medal. Will it happen?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The question asks whether any athlete will win at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics. In Olympic tennis, there are five events: men's singles, women's singles, men's doubles, women's doubles, and mixed doubles. Athletes are permitted to compete in multiple events, so it is possible for a single athlete to win multiple medals.

Historically, winning multiple medals in tennis at a single Olympics is relatively rare but not unheard of. For example, at the 2012 London Olympics, Andy Murray won gold in men's singles and silver in mixed doubles. However, in the 2016 Rio Olympics and the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, no tennis player won more than one medal.

Top singles players often focus on their singles events due to the physical and mental demands, while doubles specialists may not compete in singles. Mixed doubles partnerships are sometimes formed between top players, but the competition is fierce.

Considering the depth of talent in tennis and the scheduling challenges of competing in multiple events, the probability of an athlete winning more than one medal is low but plausible. Factors such as injuries, withdrawals, and unexpected performances can influence outcomes.

question.title: At the 2024 Olympics, will at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.background_info:
[Gold medal wins at the Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table) are concentrated in a small number of countries; the United States alone has won nearly 20% of every gold medal ever awarded, and a total of eight countries account for the majority of medalists.

Conversely, prior to the opening of the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris, there are over 100 National Olympic Committees that have never won a gold medal. In recent Games, the number of countries that won their first gold were:

* London 2012: 3
* Rio de Janeiro 2016: 9
* Tokyo 2020: 3

Will this number be 5 or more this year?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning:

**Historical Data:**

In recent Olympic Games, the number of countries winning their first-ever gold medal has been relatively low:

- **London 2012**: 1 country (Grenada)
- **Rio 2016**: 4 countries (Fiji, Jordan, Kosovo, Singapore)
- **Tokyo 2020**: 3 countries (Bermuda, Philippines, Qatar)

The highest number in the past three Olympics was four countries in Rio 2016. Achieving five or more would exceed recent historical trends.

**Potential Countries for Paris 2024:**

1. **Malaysia**:
   - *Sport*: Badminton
   - *Athletes*: Lee Zii Jia (Men's Singles)
   - *Considerations*: Malaysia has come close to gold in the past but has traditionally been edged out by powerhouses like China and Indonesia.

2. **Burkina Faso**:
   - *Sport*: Athletics (Triple Jump)
   - *Athlete*: Hugues Fabrice Zango (Bronze in Tokyo 2020)
   - *Considerations*: Zango is a strong contender but faces stiff competition from athletes from the USA and Portugal.

3. **Cyprus**:
   - *Sport*: Sailing
   - *Athlete*: Pavlos Kontides (Silver in London 2012)
   - *Considerations*: While a strong sailor, securing gold is uncertain due to variable factors in sailing competitions.

4. **Niger**:
   - *Sport*: Taekwondo
   - *Athlete*: Abdoul Razak Issoufou (Silver in Rio 2016)
   - *Considerations*: Potential for medal placement, but gold is not assured.

5. **Botswana**:
   - *Sport*: Athletics (800m)
   - *Athlete*: Nijel Amos (Bronze in London 2012)
   - *Considerations*: Faces intense competition from athletes in Kenya and other nations.

**Assessment:**

Given historical data and the current competitive landscape, it's unlikely that five or more countries will win their debut gold medals in Paris 2024. While there are strong athletes from countries that have yet to secure a gold medal, the challenges they face make it improbable for enough of them to secure gold in the same Olympic Games.

Probability: 0.1

question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.background_info:
[Medal wins at the Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table) are concentrated in a fairly small number of countries; the United States alone has won about 1 out of every 6 medals ever awarded, and a total of ten countries account for the majority of medalists.

Conversely, prior to the opening of the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris, there are about 60 National Olympic Committees that have never won a gold medal; the most recent countries to win their first medal, in the Tokyo 2020 Games, were Burkina Faso, San Marino and Turkmenistan.

Will at least 5 new countries win their first medal at the current Games?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: Historically, each Olympic Games sees a few countries winning their first-ever medals. For instance, at the 2016 Rio Olympics, countries like Kosovo, Fiji, and Jordan secured their first medals. In the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, nations such as Turkmenistan, San Marino, and Burkina Faso achieved this feat. Typically, the number ranges from 2 to 5 countries per Olympics.

As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there are still around 70 countries that have never won an Olympic medal. However, many of these nations are small or have limited resources and athletes competing at the highest levels. The pool of countries capable of breaking through is decreasing as more nations achieve their first medals.

Considering the trends, the level of competition, and the number of countries yet to win a medal, it's possible but somewhat unlikely that 5 or more countries will win their first-ever medal at the Paris 2024 Olympics. Therefore, I estimate the probability to be around 30%.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.background_info:
On June 27, 2024, Joe Biden and Donald Trump held their first debate as part of the campaign for the 2024 presidential election. Biden's debate performance was [widely seen as poor](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-trump-june-debate-poll/), and prompted calls for Biden to drop out, including [from the New York Times editorial board](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/28/opinion/biden-election-debate-trump.html) and, as of July 5, [three House Democrats](https://thehill.com/homenews/house/4755497-seth-moulton-biden-presidential-race/).

The Biden team has reportedly been [taking action](https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/04/politics/biden-rising-tide-pressure-reelection-bid-analysis/index.html) to reverse recent perceptions, and has [so far insisted](https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4754840-biden-campaign-denies-dropout-rumors/) that Biden will not be dropping out. However, the New York Times [reported](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/03/us/politics/biden-withdraw-election-debate.html) that the Biden team has internally acknowledged that they must turn perceptions around quickly.

According to [538's presidential polling average](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) (when accessed on July 5, 2024), on the date of the debate Trump held a +0.2 percentage point lead in the polling averages, which has since widened to a +2.4 percentage point lead for Trump reported for July 5. The near-term polling trend may be critical as Biden weighs whether to stay in the race ahead of the [2024 Democratic National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Democratic_National_Convention), which is scheduled to be held August 19th through the 22nd.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the 2024 U.S. Presidential election is anticipated to be a competitive race between incumbent President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump. Polling data at this stage is preliminary and subject to significant fluctuation due to various factors such as economic conditions, international events, campaign developments, and social issues.

Historically, national polling averages can vary widely, and small shifts in public opinion can lead to changes in polling margins of several percentage points within short periods. The specific range in question—a Trump lead greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 percentage points—is a narrow one-point window. Given the volatility of polling data, the likelihood of the polling average falling within this exact range on a specific future date (July 15, 2024) is relatively low.

Moreover, considering that public opinion can be influenced by unforeseen events (e.g., debates, policy announcements, scandals, economic shifts), predicting the exact margin of lead is challenging. While it's possible that Trump could be leading Biden by that margin on that date, the probability is diminished by the narrowness of the specified range and the myriad of factors that could affect polling numbers.

Taking into account the historical variability in polling data, the narrow range specified, and the uncertainties inherent in predicting public opinion more than eight months in advance, I estimate the probability of this event occurring to be approximately 10%.

question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time break the Olympic record of 9.63s?
question.body: This question resolves as Yes if the winning time of the men's 100m race is less than 9.63s.

metadata.background_info: Usain Bolt's 9.63s Olympic record has stood since the 2012 London Olympics. Will it be broken in Paris 2024?

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Olympic record for the men's 100m dash is 9.63 seconds, set by Usain Bolt at the 2012 London Olympics. The world record is 9.58 seconds, also set by Usain Bolt in 2009. Since Bolt's retirement, no sprinter has come close to matching these times. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the leading sprinters include Christian Coleman, Trayvon Bromell, Fred Kerley, and Lamont Marcell Jacobs. Their personal bests are in the 9.7 to 9.8-second range: - **Christian Coleman** has a personal best of 9.76 seconds. - **Trayvon Bromell** has a personal best of 9.76 seconds. - **Fred Kerley** has run 9.76 seconds. - **Lamont Marcell Jacobs**, the 2020 Tokyo Olympic champion, won with a time of 9.80 seconds. Breaking the Olympic record requires an athlete to run faster than 9.63 seconds, which has only been achieved by Usain Bolt. The difference between the top current times (around 9.76 seconds) and the Olympic record is approximately 0.13 seconds—a significant margin in sprinting. Factors that could influence faster times include: - **Advancements in technology**: Improvements in track surfaces and spike technology could aid faster times. - **Favorable conditions**: Optimal weather and maximum allowable tailwind (2.0 m/s) could contribute to faster performances. - **Emergence of new talent**: A breakthrough performance by an up-and-coming athlete cannot be entirely ruled out. However, given that no athlete has approached Bolt's records in recent years, and considering the typical rate of improvement at the elite level, it seems unlikely that the Olympic record will be broken at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

question.title: Will Individual Neutral Athletes Win ≥15 Gold Medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Individual Neutral Athletes collectively win 15 or more gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games. The source of resolution will be the official medal tally published by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) or other credible sources if such reporting from the IOC is unavailable. Otherwise the market will resolve to "No".

In the event that Individual Neutral Athletes are confirmed to have won 15 or more gold medals prior to the end of the Games, the market will resolve immediately to "Yes".

metadata.background_info:
As per the Olympic Committee’s [recommendations](https://olympics.com/ioc/news/strict-eligibility-conditions-in-place-as-ioc-eb-approves-individual-neutral-athletes-ains-for-the-olympic-games-paris-2024) from earlier this year, Russian and Belarusian athletes will be allowed to participate in the 2024 Games as long as they do so as so-called "Individual Neutral Athletes" (AINs), without an accompanying national flag or anthem.

The Russian Federation/Russian Olympic Committee has won an average of 19 gold medals in the last 3 Olympic Games, and Belarus has averaged  1.7.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) has not made a definitive decision regarding the participation of Russian and Belarusian athletes in the Paris 2024 Olympic Games. The participation of these athletes as 'Individual Neutral Athletes' hinges on the ongoing geopolitical situation, particularly the conflict involving Ukraine.

Historically, Russian athletes have been strong competitors in the Olympics. In the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, athletes from Russia competed under the designation of the 'Russian Olympic Committee' (ROC) due to previous doping sanctions. They secured a total of 20 gold medals during those games. If Russian athletes are permitted to compete as neutral athletes in Paris 2024, it's highly plausible that they could collectively win 15 or more gold medals.

On the other hand, if Russian and Belarusian athletes are not allowed to participate, the number of medals won by other neutral athletes is likely to be minimal. Typically, athletes competing under a neutral flag (excluding large delegations like Russia's) do not accumulate a significant number of gold medals.

Considering the IOC's past actions, they have sometimes allowed athletes to compete under a neutral flag to uphold the athletes' rights to participate, even amidst geopolitical tensions. However, there is considerable international pressure and ethical considerations due to the ongoing conflict, which may influence the IOC's decision.

Given these factors, there is substantial uncertainty. Balancing the likelihood of Russian athletes being allowed to compete as neutrals and their potential performance, I estimate the probability that Individual Neutral Athletes will win 15 or more gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics to be around 50%.

question.title: On July 21, 2024, will the closing value of BSE SENSEX be greater than 75k and less than or equal to 76k?
question.body: This question resolves as the closing value of the BSE SENSEX on July 21, 2024, according to Yahoo Finance.

metadata.background_info:
The [Bombay Stock Exchange Sensitive Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BSE_SENSEX), also known as the S&P BSE SENSEX or simply the SENSEX, is a stock market index consisting of 30 of the largest companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. It is one of the oldest and most widely followed equity indices in India. The SENSEX is intended to reflect the overall performance of the Indian stock market.

India's recent general elections saw incumbent Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), win a [narrower victory](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/india-election-modi-bjp-lost-majority-election-surprise-rcna155557) than expected, raising concerns about potential policy paralysis and the ability of the government to implement key economic reforms. As a result, in the immediate aftermath of the elections, the SENSEX has experienced significant volatility, beginning with a [drop of almost 6%](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2024/6/5/india-election-why-modis-narrow-win-has-the-stock-market-in-a-spin) on June 4th, followed by a significant bounce on June 5th.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the BSE SENSEX is trading around 66,000 points. To be greater than 75,000 but less than or equal to 76,000 on July 21, 2024, the index would need to increase by approximately 13.6% to 15.1% over roughly nine months. Historically, the BSE SENSEX has experienced annual returns that can vary widely due to market volatility influenced by economic conditions, corporate earnings, inflation rates, interest rate changes, geopolitical events, and global investor sentiment. While a 13-15% increase over nine months is achievable, it would require strong and sustained positive market conditions. However, the probability of the index not only reaching that level but also closing within a narrow 1,000-point range on a specific date is relatively low due to daily market fluctuations. The 1,000-point range represents about 1.3% of the index value at 75,000, and daily movements can easily move the index outside this range. Considering these factors, including the required market performance and the narrow range on a specific date, I estimate the probability of the BSE SENSEX closing between 75,000 and 76,000 on July 21, 2024, to be approximately 5%.
