As a result, in the immediate aftermath of the elections, the SENSEX has experienced significant volatility, beginning with a [drop of almost 6%](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2024/6/5/india-election-why-modis-narrow-win-has-the-stock-market-in-a-spin) on June 4th, followed by a significant bounce on June 5th.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the BSE SENSEX was trading around 66,000 points. To reach a closing value between 76,000 and 77,000 by July 21, 2024, the index would need to increase by approximately 15% to 17% over roughly nine months. Historically, the Indian stock market has shown strong growth due to factors such as a growing economy, positive investor sentiment, and supportive government policies. A 15% to 17% increase over nine months is ambitious but not unprecedented. For instance, in past bullish phases, the SENSEX has achieved similar or higher growth rates within comparable time frames. However, several factors could influence this outcome: 1. Economic Conditions: India's GDP growth rate, inflation, and fiscal policies will significantly impact market performance. Sustained economic growth could drive the index higher. 2. Global Factors: Global economic conditions, such as interest rate changes by major central banks, geopolitical tensions, and commodity prices, can affect investor sentiment and capital flows into emerging markets like India. 3. Corporate Earnings: Strong earnings growth from major companies listed on the SENSEX would support higher index values. 4. Market Sentiment: Investor optimism or pessimism can accelerate or dampen market movements. 5. Potential Risks: Risks such as higher-than-expected inflation, policy changes, or global economic slowdowns could impede growth. Considering these factors, while there is a reasonable chance for the SENSEX to reach the 76,000 to 77,000 range, the outcome is uncertain due to potential risks and market volatility.

question.title: On July 21, 2024, will the closing value of BSE SENSEX be greater than 75k and less than or equal to 77k?
question.body: This question resolves as the closing value of the BSE SENSEX on July 21, 2024, according to Yahoo Finance.

metadata.background_info:
The [Bombay Stock Exchange Sensitive Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BSE_SENSEX), also known as the S&P BSE SENSEX or simply the SENSEX, is a stock market index consisting of 30 of the largest companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. It is one of the oldest and most widely followed equity indices in India. The SENSEX is intended to reflect the overall performance of the Indian stock market.

India's recent general elections saw incumbent Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), win a [narrower victory](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/india-election-modi-bjp-lost-majority-election-surprise-rcna155557) than expected, raising concerns about potential policy paralysis and the ability of the government to implement key economic reforms. As a result, in the immediate aftermath of the elections, the SENSEX has experienced significant volatility, beginning with a [drop of almost 6%](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2024/6/5/india-election-why-modis-narrow-win-has-the-stock-market-in-a-spin) on June 4th, followed by a significant bounce on June 5th.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the BSE SENSEX was trading around 66,000 points. To reach a level between 75,000 and 77,000 by July 21, 2024, the index would need to increase by approximately 13.6% to 16.7% over a period of about 9 months. Historically, the Indian stock market has shown strong growth, driven by robust economic development, favorable demographic trends, and increasing foreign investment. Achieving a 13-17% gain in 9 months is plausible, especially if economic conditions remain positive, corporate earnings continue to grow, and investor sentiment stays strong. However, stock market performance is subject to various risks and uncertainties: - Global Economic Factors: Any slowdown in the global economy, changes in commodity prices, or shifts in monetary policies by major central banks can impact the Indian markets. - Domestic Challenges: Inflationary pressures, fiscal deficits, or unfavorable government policies could negatively affect market growth. - Geopolitical Tensions: Regional conflicts or trade disputes can lead to market volatility. Given these considerations, while there is a reasonable chance that the SENSEX could reach between 75,000 and 77,000, there are also significant uncertainties that could hinder this growth.

question.title: Will Kalenjin athletes win both the men's and women's marathon races at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if both the winner of the men's and winner's marathon at the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris have Kalenjin roots.

metadata.background_info: The Kalenjin people, native to Kenya, dominate racing in distances 800m and longer. Will they win both the men's and women's marathon at the 2024 Paris Olympics?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Kalenjin athletes from Kenya have historically dominated long-distance running events, particularly marathons. In the men's marathon, Eliud Kipchoge, a Kalenjin athlete, is the world record holder and won gold in both the 2016 Rio and 2020 Tokyo Olympics. If he competes in the 2024 Paris Olympics, he is a strong contender for the gold medal. Other Kalenjin male athletes are also among the top marathon runners globally.

In the women's marathon, Kalenjin athletes have also excelled. At the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, Peres Jepchirchir and Brigid Kosgei, both Kalenjin runners from Kenya, won gold and silver respectively. They remain top competitors and are likely to participate in Paris 2024.

However, there is significant competition from athletes of other nationalities, especially Ethiopians, who have historically been strong in marathon events. Additionally, factors such as injuries, changes in form, and race conditions can affect the outcomes.

Considering the dominance of Kalenjin athletes but also accounting for the strong international competition and uncertainties inherent in athletics, there is a moderate probability that both the men's and women's marathon gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics will be won by Kalenjin athletes.

question.title: Between July 17 and July 28, 2024, will the strongest geomagnetic storm have a K-index ("Kp") greater than 5 and less than or equal to 6?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the highest Planetary K-index ("Kp") between July 17 and July 28, 2024 (inclusive) is greater than 5 and less than or equal to 6, according to the German Research Center for Geosciences in their running 30-day history data product.

metadata.background_info:
In May 2024, sunspot region AR3664, now designated as AR3697, returned to face Earth after merging with another active sunspot region, resulting in numerous M- and X-class solar flares that caused intense [geomagnetic storms and auroras](https://earthsky.org/earth/auroras-last-night-extreme-solar-storm-wow-millions-may-10-11-12-2024/) visible at unusually low latitudes. 

As AR3697 [returns to face Earth](https://www.space.com/return-aurora-causing-sunspot-june-solar-storm-prospects) in early June 2024, space weather forecasters anticipate ongoing geomagnetic activity and are closely monitoring the region's continued potential to produce extreme space weather. 

[Sunspots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunspot) are areas of intense magnetic activity that often give rise to solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs), which can disturb Earth's magnetosphere and impact satellite operations, power grids, and navigation systems.

The [K-index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-index), which measures fluctuations in Earth's magnetic field, ranges from from 0 to 9. The NOAA Space Weather Scales uses the Kp values to classify the severity of geomagnetic storms from G1 (minor) to G5 (extreme), equating to Kp values of 5 to 9, respectively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The K-index (Kp) measures geomagnetic activity on a scale from 0 to 9. A Kp greater than 5 and less than or equal to 6 corresponds to a Kp of exactly 6, which indicates a moderate geomagnetic storm.

Solar activity follows an approximately 11-year cycle, with periods of solar maximum exhibiting increased geomagnetic activity. According to predictions up to my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Solar Cycle 25 is expected to peak around 2024-2025. This suggests that July 2024 will be near the solar maximum, increasing the likelihood of geomagnetic storms.

Historically, during solar maximum:

- The number of days per year with Kp = 6 is approximately 20.
- The number of days per year with Kp > 6 (i.e., Kp = 7, 8, or 9) is around 10.

Calculating daily probabilities:

- Probability of Kp = 6 on any given day: P(Kp=6) = 20/365 ≈ 0.055 or 5.5%.
- Probability of Kp > 6 on any given day: P(Kp>6) = 10/365 ≈ 0.027 or 2.7%.
- Probability of Kp ≤ 5 on any given day: P(Kp ≤ 5) = 1 - P(Kp=6) - P(Kp>6) ≈ 0.918 or 91.8%.

For the 12-day period from July 17 to July 28, 2024:

1. **Probability that no day has Kp > 6:**
   P(No Kp>6) = (P(Kp ≤ 6))^{12} = (0.973)^{12} ≈ 0.721 or 72.1%.

2. **Probability that all days have Kp ≤ 5:**
   P(All Kp ≤ 5) = (0.918)^{12} ≈ 0.361 or 36.1%.

3. **Probability that at least one day has Kp = 6 and no days have Kp > 6:**
   P(At least one Kp=6 and no Kp>6) = P(No Kp>6) - P(All Kp ≤ 5) = 0.721 - 0.361 = 0.36 or 36%.

**Conclusion:**

There is approximately a 36% probability that the highest Kp index between July 17 and July 28, 2024, will be greater than 5 and less than or equal to 6 (i.e., exactly 6), with no days exceeding Kp of 6.

question.title: Between July 17 and July 28, 2024, will the strongest geomagnetic storm have a K-index ("Kp") greater than 4 and less than or equal to 5?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the highest Planetary K-index ("Kp") between July 17 and July 28, 2024 (inclusive) is greater than 4 and less than or equal to 5, according to the German Research Center for Geosciences in their running 30-day history data product.

metadata.background_info:
In May 2024, sunspot region AR3664, now designated as AR3697, returned to face Earth after merging with another active sunspot region, resulting in numerous M- and X-class solar flares that caused intense [geomagnetic storms and auroras](https://earthsky.org/earth/auroras-last-night-extreme-solar-storm-wow-millions-may-10-11-12-2024/) visible at unusually low latitudes. 

As AR3697 [returns to face Earth](https://www.space.com/return-aurora-causing-sunspot-june-solar-storm-prospects) in early June 2024, space weather forecasters anticipate ongoing geomagnetic activity and are closely monitoring the region's continued potential to produce extreme space weather. 

[Sunspots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunspot) are areas of intense magnetic activity that often give rise to solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs), which can disturb Earth's magnetosphere and impact satellite operations, power grids, and navigation systems.

The [K-index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-index), which measures fluctuations in Earth's magnetic field, ranges from from 0 to 9. The NOAA Space Weather Scales uses the Kp values to classify the severity of geomagnetic storms from G1 (minor) to G5 (extreme), equating to Kp values of 5 to 9, respectively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Based on historical data, during periods of high solar activity approaching solar maximum—expected around 2025—minor geomagnetic storms (classified as G1 storms with a Kp index of 5) occur more frequently. On average, there are about 82 G1 storms per year during such periods, which translates to approximately 6.8 events per month.

For the 12-day period between July 17 and July 28, 2024, the expected number of G1 storms is calculated as:
\[ \lambda = \frac{82 \text{ storms/year}}{365 \text{ days/year}} \times 12 \text{ days} \approx 2.7 \text{ storms} \]

Assuming that the occurrence of these storms follows a Poisson distribution, the probability of at least one storm occurring is:
\[ P(\text{at least one event}) = 1 - e^{-\lambda} = 1 - e^{-2.7} \approx 0.93 \]

Therefore, there is approximately a 93% chance that the Kp index will be greater than 4 and less than or equal to 5 during this period. Higher levels of geomagnetic storms (Kp > 5) are less frequent and do not significantly affect this probability.

question.title: Between July 17 and July 28, 2024, will the strongest geomagnetic storm have a K-index ("Kp") greater than 4 and less than or equal to 6?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the highest Planetary K-index ("Kp") between July 17 and July 28, 2024 (inclusive) is greater than 4 and less than or equal to 6, according to the German Research Center for Geosciences in their running 30-day history data product.

metadata.background_info:
In May 2024, sunspot region AR3664, now designated as AR3697, returned to face Earth after merging with another active sunspot region, resulting in numerous M- and X-class solar flares that caused intense [geomagnetic storms and auroras](https://earthsky.org/earth/auroras-last-night-extreme-solar-storm-wow-millions-may-10-11-12-2024/) visible at unusually low latitudes. 

As AR3697 [returns to face Earth](https://www.space.com/return-aurora-causing-sunspot-june-solar-storm-prospects) in early June 2024, space weather forecasters anticipate ongoing geomagnetic activity and are closely monitoring the region's continued potential to produce extreme space weather. 

[Sunspots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunspot) are areas of intense magnetic activity that often give rise to solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs), which can disturb Earth's magnetosphere and impact satellite operations, power grids, and navigation systems.

The [K-index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-index), which measures fluctuations in Earth's magnetic field, ranges from from 0 to 9. The NOAA Space Weather Scales uses the Kp values to classify the severity of geomagnetic storms from G1 (minor) to G5 (extreme), equating to Kp values of 5 to 9, respectively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Kp index is a measure of geomagnetic activity on a scale from 0 to 9, where higher values indicate stronger geomagnetic storms. A Kp value greater than 4 signifies the onset of geomagnetic storm conditions. Specifically: - Kp = 5 corresponds to a minor geomagnetic storm (G1). - Kp = 6 corresponds to a moderate geomagnetic storm (G2). Geomagnetic storms are primarily driven by solar activity, which follows an approximately 11-year solar cycle consisting of solar minimum and solar maximum phases. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Solar Cycle 25 is underway, with the solar maximum expected around 2025. This means that in July 2024, solar activity is increasing, approaching the peak activity of the solar cycle. Historical Frequency: During periods nearing solar maximum, the frequency of geomagnetic storms increases. Historical data indicates: - Minor storms (Kp = 5): Occur approximately 100 times per year during solar maximum phases. - Moderate storms (Kp = 6): Occur about 35 times per year during active solar periods. Combined, there are roughly 135 events per year with Kp values greater than 4 and less than or equal to 6. Over a 365-day year, this averages to about one such event every 2.7 days. Calculating Probability Over 12 Days: The time frame in question is 12 days long (July 17 to July 28, 2024). To estimate the probability of at least one Kp > 4 and ≤ 6 event occurring during this period: 1. Calculate the average number of events in 12 days: Average events = (135 events / 365 days) * 12 ≈ 4.44 events 2. Assuming events occur independently (which is a simplification), the probability of at least one event occurring is high. 3. Using the Poisson distribution: The probability of observing at least one event (k ≥ 1) when the expected number of events (λ) is 4.44: P(k ≥ 1) = 1 - P(k = 0) = 1 - e^{-λ} = 1 - e^{-4.44} ≈ 0.988 Conclusion: Given the increasing solar activity leading up to the solar maximum in 2025 and the historical frequency of minor to moderate geomagnetic storms during such periods, there is a very high likelihood of at least one event with a Kp index greater than 4 and less than or equal to 6 occurring within the specified 12-day window in July 2024.

question.title: Will a swimmer win the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: The question resolves as **Yes** if the athlete with the highest number of 2024 Olympic gold medals competes in the swimming events.

metadata.background_info: A few Olympic sports - swimming, athletics, gymnastics - have athletes competing in multiple events. Will the athlete winning the most gold medals at the 2024 Games in Paris be someone competing in the swimming events?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: Historically, swimmers have often been the athletes to win the most gold medals at the Olympic Games. This is primarily because swimming offers a large number of events in which a single athlete can compete, including multiple individual distances and strokes, as well as relay events. For example, Michael Phelps won a record-breaking eight gold medals in a single Olympics (Beijing 2008), and swimmers like Katie Ledecky and Caeleb Dressel have also won multiple golds in recent Games.

At the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, American swimmer Caeleb Dressel won five gold medals, making him the athlete with the most golds at those Games. Australian swimmer Emma McKeon also had a standout performance, winning four gold and three bronze medals. Their success highlights the potential for swimmers to dominate the medal tally.

Looking ahead to the 2024 Paris Olympics, it is likely that top swimmers will again be strong contenders for the highest number of gold medals. Swimmers like Caeleb Dressel and Katie Ledecky (if they compete) are expected to participate in multiple events. In contrast, athletes in other sports typically have fewer opportunities to win multiple gold medals due to the nature of their events. While gymnasts and track and field athletes can win multiple medals, it is less common for them to achieve as many golds as swimmers.

Given the historical trends and the structure of Olympic events, there is a high probability that a swimmer will be the athlete with the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

question.title: Will the Olympic record for the men's pole vault be broken at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the winning height of the men's pole vault at the 2024 Paris Olympics is 6.04m or higher.

metadata.background_info:
Brazilian pole vaulter Thiago Braz set the Olympic record at 6.03m at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics. Since then, the world record has risen to 6.24m, set by Swedish athlete Armand Duplantis earlier in 2024.

With Braz suspended from the current Games, will his record be broken Duplantis or another competitor?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the current Olympic record for the men's pole vault is 6.03 meters, set by Thiago Braz da Silva of Brazil at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics. The world record is held by Armand "Mondo" Duplantis of Sweden, who has consistently broken the world record multiple times, most recently setting it at 6.23 meters in 2023.

Duplantis has been dominating the pole vault scene and consistently clearing heights well above 6 meters in international competitions. His performance trajectory suggests that he's capable of surpassing the Olympic record of 6.03 meters. The Olympic Games often serve as a platform for top athletes to achieve their personal bests due to the high level of competition and motivation.

However, factors such as weather conditions, injury risks, equipment issues, and the pressure of the Olympic stage can affect performance. While Duplantis is the favorite, these variables introduce some uncertainty.

Considering his exceptional form and the likelihood of him attempting to break the Olympic record, there is a high probability that the record will be broken at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

question.title: Will the US government end its agreement directly allowing Verisign to manage the authoritative domain name registry for the .com TLD, before August 3, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if before August 3, 2024, the US Department of Commerce (DOC) officially terminates or sunsets its Cooperative Agreement with Verisign recognizing Verisign's management of the *.com* generic top-level domain (TLD). If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.background_info:
[Verisign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verisign) operates the authoritative registry for the .com generic top-level domain (TLD) under a registry agreement with the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) and a [Cooperative Agreement](https://www.ntia.gov/page/verisign-cooperative-agreement) with the US Department of Commerce (DOC). This means it is the wholesale provider of the .com TLD to every domain name registrar. The American Economic Liberties Projected [has called](https://www.economicliberties.us/press-release/ntia-and-doj-must-break-verisigns-monopoly-power-over-domain-names-advocates-urge/) this arrangement a "government-designated monopoly over domain registration." According to [The American Prospect](https://prospect.org/power/2024-06-27-government-created-most-profitable-company-verisign/):

>You have probably never heard of the most profitable company in America, and possibly the world. It’s a government-granted monopoly that feasts on high margins for a low-dollar administrative product. Today, three advocacy groups pressured the Biden administration to take down the rules in place that enable this gravy train.

>The company is called VeriSign [*sic*], and it has exclusive control of the registration system for the .com domain name. Every year, hundreds of millions of website owners pay VeriSign [*sic*] a small annual fee to keep their .com in working order. Every year, the cost of managing the database to make sure that .com websites work either stays flat or goes down, while the fee for registering a .com website goes up.

The Cooperative Agreement between Verisign and the US DOC will automatically renew for a six-year term unless the DOC provides notice of non-renewal on August 2, 2024.

According to [Bloomberg](https://archive.ph/IXZ3V#selection-1705.0-1726.0), during the 2018 renewal the Trump Administration lifted the cap on wholesale prices for *.com*. The antitrust advocacy groups have written to the Justice Department to withdraw guidance that allowed the elimination of price caps in the 2018 renewal, with the letters citing President Biden’s 2021 [executive order](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/07/09/executive-order-on-promoting-competition-in-the-american-economy/) on competition.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Verisign has had a longstanding Cooperative Agreement with the U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC) to manage the .com top-level domain (TLD) since the 1990s. This agreement has been renewed and amended multiple times, reflecting a stable relationship between Verisign and the DOC. There have been no public indications or announcements suggesting that the DOC intends to terminate this agreement before August 3, 2024. Terminating such a critical agreement would involve significant regulatory processes, stakeholder consultations, and planning to ensure the stability of the internet's infrastructure. The .com TLD is a vital part of global internet operations, and any changes in its management would require a substantial transition period. Additionally, the most recent amendments to the agreement have focused on allowing Verisign to continue its role, sometimes with adjusted terms, rather than terminating it. Given the historical precedent of renewals and the absence of any current signals pointing toward termination, it is highly unlikely that the U.S. government will end its agreement with Verisign before the specified date.

question.title: Will the domestic box office opening of "Deadpool & Wolverine" be higher than that of "Deadpool" and "The Wolverine" combined?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the domestic box office opening for the **Deadpool & Wolverine** reported by Boxofficemojo on the [movie's page](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/title/tt6263850/?ref_=bo_se_r_1) is higher than $185,548,391 which is the sum of the box openings for **Deadpool** (2016) and **The Wolverine** (2013): $132,434,639 + $53,113,752.

metadata.background_info:
**Deadpool & Wolverine** is an upcoming blockbuster by Marvel Studios scheduled to be released on July 26, 2024 featuring the two iconic heroes from the X-Men Universe.

The recent projection from Deadline puts the domestic opening to [$160-$165 million](https://deadline.com/2024/07/deadpool-wolverine-box-office-opening-projection-1236000799/), which would not only be the best opening year-to-date (beating **Inside Out 2** with $154 million) but also a record start for an R-rated movie. 

Another projection from June was even higher, [at $200+ million](https://deadline.com/2024/06/deadpool-wolverine-box-office-projection-1235973545/).

The ticket seller Fandango [reported on May 21](https://www.gamespot.com/articles/deadpool-and-wolverine-has-strongest-day-one-ticket-pre-sales-in-franchise-history-at-fandango/1100-6523599/) that their ticket pre-sales for the movie were the site's biggest ones in 2024 up to date.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, "Deadpool 3" is scheduled for release on May 3, 2024. This film is highly anticipated due to the return of Ryan Reynolds as Deadpool and Hugh Jackman reprising his role as Wolverine, marking Wolverine's entry into the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU). The collaboration of these two popular characters could potentially attract a large audience.

**Historical Box Office Performances:**

- **"Deadpool" (2016):** Opened to **$132.4 million** domestically.
- **"Deadpool 2" (2018):** Opened to **$125.5 million** domestically.
- **"The Wolverine" (2013):** Opened to **$53.1 million** domestically.
- **"Logan" (2017):** Opened to **$88.4 million** domestically.

The combined opening of "Deadpool" and "The Wolverine" is **$185.5 million**.

**Factors Influencing the Opening Weekend Gross:**

1. **Star Power and Fan Anticipation:**
   - The return of Hugh Jackman as Wolverine is a significant draw.
   - The merging of Deadpool into the MCU could boost interest.

2. **MCU Integration:**
   - Being part of the larger MCU may attract a broader audience.
   - Previous MCU films have had strong opening weekends.

3. **R-Rating:**
   - "Deadpool 3" is expected to maintain an R-rating.
   - R-rated films typically have lower openings compared to PG-13 films due to audience restrictions.
   - Example: Despite strong performances, neither "Deadpool" nor "Deadpool 2" surpassed $133 million on opening weekends.

4. **Market Conditions:**
   - Post-pandemic box office recovery is ongoing but uncertain.
   - Audience behaviors have shifted towards streaming platforms.

5. **Competition:**
   - Potential competing releases around the same date could impact box office numbers.

6. **Marketing and Hype:**
   - An effective marketing campaign could boost ticket sales.
   - Teasers, trailers, and promotions featuring both characters will influence audience excitement.

7. **Potential Delays:**
   - The 2023 writers' and actors' strikes could affect the release schedule.
   - Any delays past July 29, 2024, would result in the question resolving as "No."

**Assessment:**

While there is substantial excitement around "Deadpool 3," surpassing an opening weekend gross of $185.5 million is challenging:

- Only major ensemble MCU films (e.g., "Avengers: Endgame" with $357 million) have crossed that threshold.
- "Spider-Man: No Way Home" (2021), with significant nostalgia factors, opened at $260 million.
- An R-rating limits the potential audience size compared to PG-13 films.

Considering these factors, it's plausible but unlikely that "Deadpool 3" will achieve an opening weekend over $185.5 million.

question.title: Will at least 24 world records be broken at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the number of world records broken during the Paris Olympics is 24 or greater.

metadata.background_info:
In the last three Summer Olympics, the number of world records broken was:

London 2012: 32
Rio de Janeiro 2016: 23
Tokyo 2020: 27

In '24, will 24 or more records be broken?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning:

Historically, the number of world records broken at the Summer Olympics varies:

- **London 2012**: Approximately 32 world records were set.
- **Rio 2016**: Around 27 world records were broken.
- **Tokyo 2020** (held in 2021): Approximately 20 world records were achieved.

There appears to be a slight downward trend in the number of world records broken in recent Olympics. Several factors could influence the number of world records at the **Paris 2024 Olympics**:

1. **Advancements in Technology and Training**: Continuous improvements in athletic training, nutrition, and equipment can enhance performances, potentially leading to more world records.
   
2. **Introduction of New Events**: If new sports or events are added to the Olympic program, there may be more opportunities for athletes to set initial world records.

3. **Post-Pandemic Recovery**: The COVID-19 pandemic impacted athlete preparations for Tokyo 2020. With more normalized training conditions leading up to Paris 2024, athletes may perform better.

4. **Increased Competition**: The ever-growing global competitiveness in sports can push athletes to achieve new heights.

However, as records become tougher to break over time, setting new world records becomes increasingly challenging. Considering these factors, it's plausible but not certain that at least 24 world records will be broken at Paris 2024.

question.title: Will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question resolves as No if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, voleyball and water polo.

Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as **Yes**.

metadata.background_info:
Although most events in the Summer Olympics are contested by individual athletes, or small teams of 2-4, a few have one single larger team representing their entire country. These are:

Association football
Basketball 5×5
Basketball 3×3
Field hockey
Handball
Rugby sevens
Volleyball
Water polo

(Beach volleyball is listed on the source but excluded from the question because two teams from each team can qualify, unlike the other sports.)

Will the women's teams of the same nation win at least two of these sports?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To determine the likelihood that the same nation will win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics, we need to analyze the strengths and historical performances of top nations across the eight specified sports: association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo.

**United States (USA)**:

- **5×5 Basketball**: The USA women's basketball team is historically dominant, having won the gold medal in the last seven consecutive Olympics (1996-2020). Their depth of talent and strong development programs make them the clear favorites for gold in 2024.

- **Water Polo**: The USA women's water polo team has been the world's leading team, winning gold in the last three Olympics (2012, 2016, 2020) and multiple World Championships. They are the favorites to secure gold again in 2024.

- **3×3 Basketball**: Introduced in the 2020 Olympics, the USA women's team won the inaugural gold medal. They are strong contenders to repeat this success in 2024 given their pool of talented players and experience.

- **Volleyball**: The USA women's volleyball team won gold in 2020 and consistently ranks among the top teams globally. They are strong contenders for a medal, including gold, in 2024.

- **Association Football**: While historically dominant, the USA women's soccer team experienced a surprising early exit in the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup. However, they remain a top team with potential to regroup and contend for gold in 2024.

**Netherlands**:

- **Field Hockey**: The Netherlands women's field hockey team is the dominant force internationally, having won gold in 2008, 2012, and 2020, and silver in 2016. They are strong favorites to win gold in 2024.

- **Water Polo**: The Dutch women's water polo team is competitive but not the top favorite. While they could contend for a medal, gold is less certain.

**France** (Host Nation):

- **Handball**: France won gold in women's handball at the 2020 Olympics and benefits from strong domestic leagues. As hosts, they have the advantage of home support and are strong contenders for gold.

- **Basketball**: The French women's basketball team is competitive, having won bronze in 2020. They are contenders but face stiff competition from the USA.

**Spain**:

- **Association Football**: Spain won the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup, showcasing their rising prominence in women's football. They are strong contenders for Olympic gold in 2024.

- **Water Polo**: Spain's women's water polo team won silver in both the 2012 and 2020 Olympics. They are among the top teams and could contend for gold.

**Australia**:

- **Rugby Sevens**: Australia won gold in women's rugby sevens at the 2016 Olympics and bronze in 2020. They are strong contenders alongside New Zealand.

- **Basketball**: Australia's women's basketball team is traditionally strong but has faced challenges in recent years. They are contenders but not the top favorites.

**Assessment**:

Given this analysis, the USA is the most likely nation to win more than one women's team sport gold medal in the 2024 Olympics, with strong chances in 5×5 basketball, water polo, 3×3 basketball, and potential in volleyball and football. The combination of historical dominance and depth of talent increases their likelihood.

Other nations like the Netherlands and France have strong prospects in one sport but less likelihood of securing multiple golds due to intense competition and fewer top-tier teams across these sports.

**Conclusion**:

Considering the USA's strong potential to win multiple golds and the lower probability of other nations doing the same, there is a high likelihood that the same nation will win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics.

question.title: Will an athlete win more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

metadata.background_info: Tennis at the Olympics has five events: singles for men and women, and doubles for men, women and mixed. This makes it possible for the same athlete to win more than one medal. Will it happen?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: Historically, it is not uncommon for tennis players to win multiple medals in a single Olympic Games due to the opportunity to compete in multiple events: singles, doubles, and mixed doubles. For example:

- **2020 Tokyo Olympics**: Belinda Bencic of Switzerland won gold in women's singles and silver in women's doubles.
- **2016 Rio Olympics**: Although no tennis player won multiple medals, several competed in multiple events.
- **2012 London Olympics**: Serena Williams won gold in both women's singles and women's doubles with her sister Venus Williams.
  
Top players often participate in both singles and doubles events to maximize their chances of winning medals. Players like Novak Djokovic, Ashleigh Barty, or emerging talents may choose to compete in multiple events in Paris. Additionally, the inclusion of mixed doubles provides another avenue for athletes to earn multiple medals.

Given the historical precedent and the structure of Olympic tennis competitions, there is a significant possibility that at least one athlete will win more than one medal in tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

Looking ahead to Paris 2024:

question.title: Will Poland win the 2024 Warhammer 40,000 World Team Championship?
question.body: This question will resolve Yes if Poland is the winner of the WTC 2024 as announced on the official site or the official social media of the organisation.

metadata.background_info:
Warhammer 40,000 is a miniature wargame produced by Games Workshop. Set in the far future, players collect, assemble, and paint miniature figures representing warriors, creatures, and vehicles from various factions. Players then pit their armies against each other on a tabletop battlefield. Warhammer 40,000 is currently the [most popular](https://icv2.com/print/article/56556) miniature wargame in the world.

Each year, the World Team Championship (WTC) is organized, where 8-player teams from around the world compete against each other. The teams are separated into 4 seeding groups based on past performance. In the group stage of the tournament, 10 groups are formed with 4 teams each (one from each seeding group). Group stage performance determines the overall ranking among teams, which then compete in a further 4 games following a [Swiss format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swiss-system_tournament). The team with the most total points from the group and Swiss stages is crowned the winner.

This year, the WTC takes place in Mechelen, Belgium from August 8th to 11th. 40 national teams are competing, including 5 first-time competitors: Andorra, China, Mexico, Singapore/Thailand, and South Korea. The full list of teams and seeding groups can be found [here](https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=847246644093139). Past performance can be found [here](https://worldteamchampionship.com/about/history/).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Poland has historically been a strong contender in the Warhammer 40,000 World Team Championship (WTC). As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Poland has consistently placed highly in previous championships and has won the event multiple times. Their players are known for their strategic expertise and dedication to the game, making them one of the top teams internationally. However, the WTC is highly competitive, with other strong teams such as Germany, England, the United States, and others also vying for the title. The outcome can be influenced by various factors, including changes in game mechanics, team compositions, and the emerging meta leading up to the event. Given the competitive nature of the championship and the presence of several top-tier teams, it's difficult to assign a high probability to any single team winning. While Poland's chances are better than most due to their strong track record, there is still significant uncertainty.

question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time break the Olympic record of 9.63s?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete runs the Men's 100M race at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics in less than 9.63s, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.background_info:
The [100m dash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_metres) is one of the highlights of track and field events, with the world champion often referred to as "the world's fastest man".

The [current Olympic record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men%27s_100_metres_world_record_progression) was set by Jamaican sprinter Usain Bolt's at the 2012 London Olympics. Will it be broken in Paris 2024?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The men's 100m Olympic record is 9.63 seconds, set by Usain Bolt at the 2012 London Olympics. Since then, no athlete has broken this record in subsequent Olympic Games or major international competitions. At the 2016 Rio Olympics, Bolt won with a time of 9.81 seconds, and at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, Lamont Marcell Jacobs claimed gold with 9.80 seconds.

In recent years, the fastest times recorded by active athletes are:

- **Christian Coleman** (USA): Personal best of 9.76 seconds (2019).
- **Trayvon Bromell** (USA): Personal best of 9.76 seconds (2021).
- **Fred Kerley** (USA): Personal best of 9.76 seconds (2022).
- **Akani Simbine** (South Africa): Personal best of 9.84 seconds (2021).
- **Lamont Marcell Jacobs** (Italy): Personal best of 9.80 seconds (2021).

While these athletes are exceptionally fast, none have come close to the Olympic record of 9.63 seconds in competition. Additionally, running times under 9.70 seconds are extremely rare and have been achieved by only a few sprinters in history, most notably Usain Bolt and Tyson Gay.

Factors that influence sprint times at the Olympics include:

- **Competition Pressure**: The Olympics are high-pressure events, which can affect athlete performance.
- **Track Conditions**: Weather and track conditions in Paris could impact sprint times negatively or positively.
- **Advancements in Training and Equipment**: While there are continual improvements, there haven't been significant breakthroughs likely to shave off the necessary time to break the record.

Given the historical data and current trends, it is unlikely that the Olympic record will be broken at the 2024 Paris Olympics. While it's possible that an athlete could have an exceptional performance, the probability of someone running under 9.63 seconds is relatively low.

question.title: At the 2024 Olympics, will at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.background_info:
[Gold medal wins at the Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table) are concentrated in a small number of countries; the United States alone has won nearly 20% of every gold medal ever awarded, and a total of eight countries account for the majority of medalists.

Conversely, prior to the opening of the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris, there are over 100 National Olympic Committees that have never won a gold medal. In recent Games, the number of countries that won their first gold were:

* London 2012: 3
* Rio de Janeiro 2016: 9
* Tokyo 2020: 3

Will this number be 5 or more this year?

metadata.chain_of_thought:
In recent Olympic Games, several countries have won their first-ever gold medals. For example, at the 2016 Rio Olympics, seven countries achieved this milestone: Bahrain, Fiji, Côte d'Ivoire, Jordan, Kosovo, Puerto Rico, and Singapore. In contrast, the 2020 Tokyo Olympics saw three countries—Bermuda, the Philippines, and Qatar—win their first gold medals.

The number of debut gold-winning countries fluctuates due to various factors such as emerging talent, increased investment in sports programs, and the introduction of new sports where athletes from different nations may excel. The trend demonstrates that while it's not common for many countries to win their first golds simultaneously, it is possible under favorable circumstances.

Considering that the Paris 2024 Olympics may offer new opportunities with added events and that athletes from nations without prior gold medals are continually improving, there is a moderate chance that at least five countries will secure their first-ever gold medals.

question.title: Will the Venezuelan electoral commission publish full results of the July 28 presidential election before August 12, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as Yes if [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report that, before Monday, August 12, 2024 at 12:01 AM Venezuelan Standard Time (VET), any entity of the Venezuelan government has published results of the July 28, 2024 election purporting to represent 100% of the votes cast, disaggregated to the level of parish (*parroquia*, a subdivision of municipalities).

metadata.background_info:
On July 28, Venezuela held Presidential elections, but full results have not yet been published by the [National Electoral Council (CNE)](https://www.cne.gob.ve/) as of August 2. Hours after polling stations closed, the head of the CNE proclaimed the incumbent, Nicolás Maduro, the winner for a third term.

The opposition and the international community have pointed out irregularities. The CNE [asserted](https://mincyt.gob.ve/nicolas-maduro-gana-las-elecciones-presidenciales/), with 20% of ballots left to count, that Maduro's 7-point lead over the united opposition candidate Edmundo González was "irreversible", which is contradictory – by the CNE's own assertion, there were enough votes left to be counted that González could still take the lead.

Furthermore, the data published by the CNE reports no more than three numbers: the votes for Maduro (51.2% of the total), the ones for González (44.2%), and an aggregated figure for "others" (4.6%). [Analyses of the data](https://elpais.com/america/2024-08-02/quien-gano-en-venezuela-los-datos-de-la-oposicion-son-mas-verificables-que-los-oficiales.html) show that the numbers correspond *exactly* to those percentages, a result consistent with the percentages being made up and the corresponding vote counts being calculated back from them.

Meanwhile, civil society in the country has been performing an [independent, bottom-up verification of the results](https://resultadosconvzla.com/); reports generated immediately after the election by the voting machines in precincts around the country are digitized and posted online. Aggregation of these vote counts show a 37-point victory for González over Maduro.

How will the Chavista president respond? Will he publish a full, disaggregated count of the results?

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Venezuela holds presidential elections every six years, with the last election having taken place in May 2018. This suggests that the next presidential election is scheduled for 2024. For the purpose of this question, we are considering an election date of July 28, 2024. Historically, the Venezuelan National Electoral Council (CNE) has released election results relatively promptly after the polls close. They typically provide detailed results that include breakdowns by region, municipality, and parish (parroquia). However, political instability, economic challenges, and questions about the transparency of the electoral process have been recurrent issues in Venezuela. Despite these challenges, the CNE has a track record of publishing full election results, including disaggregated data, within days to weeks after the election. Given that August 12, 2024, is approximately two weeks after the election date, it is reasonable to expect that the CNE would have released the full results by then. There is a possibility of delays due to political unrest, disputes over election legitimacy, or technical issues. However, unless there is a significant disruption, it is likely that the Venezuelan government will publish the full election results before the specified deadline.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

metadata.background_info:
The 2024 Olympic Games is a sporting competition which takes place every four years. It involves a range of different events across multiple sports.

At the Olympic Games, Gold, Silver and Bronze medals are awarded to 1st, 2nd and 3rd place in each event. (In some events two Bronze medals are awarded mostly combat sports).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that the USA will win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics, we'll analyze the historical performance of the United States in recent Olympic Games.

- **2008 Beijing Olympics**: The USA won 36 Gold and 38 Silver medals. (More Silver than Gold)
- **2012 London Olympics**: The USA won 46 Gold and 28 Silver medals. (More Gold than Silver)
- **2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics**: The USA won 46 Gold and 37 Silver medals. (More Gold than Silver)
- **2020 Tokyo Olympics**: The USA won 39 Gold and 41 Silver medals. (More Silver than Gold)

In the last four Olympics, the USA had more Gold than Silver medals in two instances (2012 and 2016) and more Silver than Gold in the other two (2008 and 2020). This historical data suggests a roughly 50% chance of either outcome.

However, several factors might influence the outcome in Paris 2024:

1. **Athlete Preparation**: With the disruption of training schedules due to the COVID-19 pandemic affecting the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, athletes may have better preparation and performance in 2024.

2. **Motivation and Competition**: The USA often fields strong teams and may be motivated to improve upon previous performances, aiming for more Gold medals.

3. **Emerging Competitors**: Other countries are increasingly competitive, which could impact the USA's ability to secure Gold medals over Silver.

Considering the historical 50% probability and these influencing factors, it's reasonable to assign a slightly higher probability to the USA winning more Gold than Silver medals. This accounts for the USA's traditionally strong Olympic performance and potential improvements in preparation for Paris 2024.

question.title: Iran military response before August 13th midnight Eastern Time?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Iran initiates a military action on Israeli soil, airspace, or maritime territory between July 30 and August 12, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

For the purposes of this market, a "military action" will be considered to be any use of force executed by Iran on Israeli soil, airspace, or maritime territory (e.g. if a weapons depot on Israeli soil is hit by an Iranian missile, this market will resolve to "Yes") that is officially acknowledged by the Iranian government or a consensus of credible reporting. This includes, but is not limited to, airstrikes, naval attacks, or ground invasions. Cyber attacks, sanctions, or diplomatic actions will not count towards the resolution of this market.

Only responses by Iranian forces explicitly claimed by the Islamic Republic of Iran, or confirmed to have originated from Iranian territory will count toward the resolution of this market. Attacks on Israel by proxy forces (i.e. Hezbollah, Houthis, etc.) will not count toward the resolution of this market.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Based on the historical context and geopolitical dynamics up to my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, it is unlikely that Iran will initiate a direct military action against Israel between July 30 and August 12, 2024. Iran has historically engaged with Israel indirectly through proxy groups like Hezbollah and Hamas rather than through direct military engagement. Direct military action would represent a significant escalation and could provoke a strong military response from Israel and potentially involve other countries, increasing the risks for Iran. Furthermore, initiating direct conflict would have substantial political and economic repercussions for Iran, including international condemnation and potential sanctions or military intervention by allies of Israel, such as the United States. The narrow time frame specified reduces the likelihood even further, as there are no known events scheduled during that period that might trigger such an escalation. While regional tensions are high and unforeseen events could alter the current state of affairs, the probability of Iran conducting a direct military action against Israel within the specified dates remains low.

Over the past few years, monthly Core CPI increases have typically ranged between 0.2% and 0.4%. Efforts by the Federal Reserve to control inflation through interest rate adjustments have aimed to slow down price increases, but core inflation has remained relatively persistent due to factors like wage growth, supply chain adjustments, and strong consumer demand in certain sectors. Barring an unexpected economic downturn or deflationary pressures, it's unlikely that the Core CPI increase for July 2024 would drop to 0.1% or lower. metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the USD/JPY exchange rate was around 149-150 JPY per USD. This strength of the USD against the JPY has been primarily due to the divergence in monetary policies between the U.S. Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan (BoJ). The Federal Reserve has been raising interest rates to combat inflation, making the USD more attractive to investors. In contrast, the BoJ has maintained an ultra-loose monetary policy with negative interest rates and yield curve control to stimulate its economy.

Looking ahead to August 9th, 2024, several factors could influence the exchange rate:

1. **Monetary Policy**: If the Federal Reserve continues its tight monetary policy while the BoJ maintains or increases its accommodative stance, the interest rate differential would likely keep the USD strong against the JPY.

2. **Economic Indicators**: U.S. economic data showing robust growth and controlled inflation would support a stronger USD. Conversely, if Japan's economy shows significant improvement, the JPY could strengthen.

3. **Geopolitical Risks**: Global events could lead to safe-haven flows into the JPY, traditionally seen as a safe currency during times of uncertainty, potentially strengthening it against the USD.

4. **Market Sentiment**: Investor sentiment and risk appetite can cause fluctuations. A shift towards risk-off sentiment could benefit the JPY.

Given the current conditions and assuming no major shifts in monetary policies or unexpected global events, it is likely that the USD will remain strong against the JPY. Therefore, the probability that the USD will be worth >= 145 JPY at the close on August 9th, 2024, is relatively high.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The current Electoral College probability for Kamala Harris in Nate Silver's model is 46.6% as of August 3, 2024. The question is whether this probability will be greater than 46.6% on August 9, 2024, at 8:40 PM, effectively asking if her odds will improve over the next week according to the model.

Over a one-week period during an election cycle, several factors can influence a candidate's projected chances:

1. **Polling Data**: New polls may be released, showing shifts in voter preferences. However, unless there's a significant change, polling shifts over a week are typically minor.

2. **Campaign Events**: Rallies, speeches, or announcements can sway public opinion. Unless a major event is scheduled, these effects are usually limited.

3. **News Developments**: Unexpected news, such as scandals or major endorsements, can impact a candidate's odds. Without knowledge of any impending news, we can't factor this in.

4. **Statistical Variability**: Models inherently have some degree of fluctuation due to the incorporation of new data and adjustments in weighting.

Given that:

- **No Specific Events Known**: There's no information about significant events scheduled in the next week that would markedly improve Harris's odds.

- **Statistical Noise**: Minor fluctuations are as likely to decrease her probability as they are to increase it.

- **Historical Precedent**: Historically, candidate probabilities don't dramatically change in the absence of major events within a short timeframe.

Therefore, without evidence pointing toward a reason for her odds to specifically increase, the probability that her Electoral College chance will be greater than 46.6% in a week is approximately equal to the probability that it will decrease. Considering this symmetry and the lack of additional information, a reasonable estimate is that there is a 50% chance her probability will increase.

Given the historical data and these considerations, while there's a possibility that "Trap" could surpass $20 million if it gains significant attention, the more likely scenario—based on recent trends—is that it will open below that threshold.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, "Kagurabachi" is a newly serialized manga in Weekly Shonen Jump. Weekly Shonen Jump operates on a weekly release schedule, with new chapters published every week except during scheduled magazine breaks or if an author takes a personal hiatus due to health or other reasons.

Scheduled breaks for Weekly Shonen Jump typically occur around major Japanese holidays such as New Year's (late December to early January) and Golden Week (late April to early May). In mid-August, Japan observes the Obon festival, a time when many people travel to visit family graves. However, Weekly Shonen Jump does not always take a break during Obon, and any breaks are usually announced in advance.

Given that chapters 44 and 45 of "Kagurabachi" are expected to be released around late July to early August 2024, there are no customary magazine breaks during this period. Unless there is an announced hiatus by the author or an unexpected event that impacts publication (such as sudden illness or unforeseen circumstances), it is likely that there will be no break between these chapters.

However, it's important to account for uncertainties such as potential health issues of the creator or other unforeseen events that could lead to a break. Given these factors, while a break is possible, it is not highly probable based on the information available up to October 2023.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Sha'Carri Richardson is one of the leading female sprinters in the world. Here are the factors influencing the probability of her winning a gold medal at the 2024 Paris Olympic Games: 1. Recent Performance: - 2023 World Championships: Richardson won the gold medal in the women's 100 meters at the 2023 World Athletics Championships in Budapest. This victory demonstrates her ability to compete and win against the world's best, including top contenders from Jamaica like Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce and Shericka Jackson. - Consistency: Throughout the 2023 season, Richardson has shown consistent performance with several sub-10.80 times, indicating her peak form. 2. Competition: - Jamaican Sprinters: The Jamaican athletes, particularly Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, Shericka Jackson, and Elaine Thompson-Herah, remain strong competitors. They've historically dominated the sprint events and are likely to be major contenders in Paris. - Emerging Talent: New athletes may emerge in the months leading up to the Olympics, adding to the competition. 3. Relay Events: - 4x100m Relay: Richardson may be part of the U.S. women's 4x100m relay team. The U.S. team is traditionally strong but has faced stiff competition from Jamaica and has occasionally been plagued by baton exchange issues. - Team Selection: Final relay team selections are often made close to the event, and performance at the U.S. Olympic Trials will be crucial. 4. Injury and Fitness: - Health Risks: Sprinting is high-intensity and has a risk of injuries which can occur unexpectedly and impact performance. - Training and Preparation: How Richardson manages her training and stays injury-free will significantly affect her chances. 5. Psychological Factors: - Pressure of the Olympics: The Olympics bring immense pressure. Richardson missed the Tokyo 2020 Olympics due to a suspension, so Paris 2024 will be her Olympic debut. - Mental Readiness: Her ability to handle the Olympic spotlight will be crucial. 6. Historical Context: - U.S. Women's Sprinting: The last American woman to win Olympic gold in the 100m was Gail Devers in 1996. Breaking this long drought adds both motivation and pressure. **Probability Calculation:** - Probability of Winning 100m Gold: Considering her form and competition, estimated at 40%. - Probability of Winning 200m Gold: Given stronger competitors and her performance, estimated at 15%. - Probability of Winning Relay Gold: Accounting for team dynamics and competition, estimated at 35%. - Combined Probability: The chance of her winning at least one gold medal can be calculated using the complement rule. Calculating the probability that she does not win any gold: - P(No Gold) = (1 - 0.40) * (1 - 0.15) * (1 - 0.35) = 0.60 * 0.85 * 0.65 ≈ 0.3315 Therefore, the probability that she wins at least one gold medal is: - 1 - P(No Gold) = 1 - 0.3315 = 0.6685 **Conclusion:** Taking into account all these factors, I estimate the probability of Sha'Carri Richardson winning a gold medal in any event at the 2024 Paris Olympic Games to be approximately 67%.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, the Philippines and China have ongoing territorial disputes in the South China Sea, particularly over features like the Spratly Islands and Scarborough Shoal. Tensions have periodically escalated due to incidents involving fishing vessels, coast guard ships, and military installations on disputed islands. The Philippines has been strengthening its alliances, notably with the United States, to counterbalance China's assertiveness in the region. China views these moves with apprehension, potentially increasing friction between the two nations. Moreover, nationalistic sentiments in both countries can exacerbate reactions to incidents in the disputed areas. However, despite these tensions, both countries have historically avoided taking extreme diplomatic measures such as expelling diplomats or recalling ambassadors. Such actions are severe and can significantly escalate conflicts, which neither country may desire given their economic ties and regional stability concerns. Considering the pattern of past interactions, the likelihood of reaching a point where diplomats are expelled or recalled is moderate but not high. While there is potential for incidents that could strain relations further, both governments have incentives to manage disputes without severing diplomatic channels. Therefore, I estimate the probability of diplomatic expulsions or recalls between the Philippines and China before August 1, 2024, to be approximately 20%.

question.title: Will there be a break between Chainsaw Man chapters 173 and 174?
question.body:
A break can be any amount of time, enough for Shonen Jump to state at the end of chapters if there will be a break before the next one.

“YES” = “Yes, there will be a break after chapter 173”

“NO” = “No, there will not be a break after chapter 173”

Plan to close this on official release, will close earlier if known-accurate leakers post any details about a break ahead of time. I do not vote in my own questions.

Breaks between chapters occur for various reasons: the author's need for rest, production quality maintenance, holidays, or editorial decisions. Tatsuki Fujimoto is known for taking breaks when necessary to ensure the quality of his work. Additionally, Shonen Jump+ offers more flexible scheduling compared to the weekly Shonen Jump magazine, which can result in less predictable release patterns.

Predicting a break between specific future chapters like 173 and 174 is challenging due to the lack of a fixed release pattern and potential unforeseen circumstances affecting publication. Given the history of occasional breaks in "Chainsaw Man" releases and the factors that contribute to them, there is a reasonable chance that a break could occur after chapter 173.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden is alive and serving as the President of the United States. Born on November 20, 1942, he will be 81 years old in July 2024. While advanced age does increase health risks, there have been no publicly reported severe health issues that would suggest a high likelihood of his passing within a specific short time frame.

According to actuarial life tables, the annual mortality rate for an 81-year-old male in the United States is approximately 5.3%. This translates to a daily mortality rate of about 0.0145% (5.3% divided by 365 days). Over a three-day period—from July 23rd to July 26th, 2024—the cumulative probability of death is roughly 0.0435% (0.0145% multiplied by 3).

Considering President Biden's access to high-quality healthcare and security, his risk of sudden health events or accidents is likely lower than that of the general population. Therefore, the probability of him passing away before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, is very low.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, "Deadpool 3" is scheduled for release on May 3, 2024. The film will feature Ryan Reynolds reprising his role as Deadpool and Hugh Jackman returning as Wolverine. This crossover is highly anticipated by fans and is significant because it brings together two of the most popular characters in the Marvel universe, especially with Wolverine returning after what was thought to be his final appearance in "Logan" (2017).

The previous record for the biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is held by "Deadpool" (2016), which grossed approximately $284.5 million globally in its opening weekend, including $152.2 million domestically. The success of the original "Deadpool" was attributed to its fresh take on the superhero genre, effective marketing, and strong fan support.

Several factors suggest that "Deadpool 3" could surpass this record:

1. **Star Power and Crossover Appeal:** The combination of Deadpool and Wolverine in a single film is a significant draw. Hugh Jackman's return as Wolverine is a major event that can attract both Deadpool fans and long-time X-Men enthusiasts.

2. **Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) Integration:** With Disney's acquisition of 21st Century Fox, Deadpool is now part of the MCU. This integration can lead to a wider audience reach, as MCU films tend to perform exceptionally well at the box office.

3. **Marketing and Hype:** Given the novelty of the crossover and the surprise return of Hugh Jackman, the marketing campaign is likely to be robust and generate substantial buzz leading up to the release.

4. **Pent-Up Demand:** The delays and disruptions in film releases due to the COVID-19 pandemic have led to increased anticipation for major blockbuster films.

However, there are factors that could potentially limit the box office performance:

1. **R-Rating Constraints:** Being R-rated restricts younger audiences from attending, which can cap the maximum potential audience compared to PG-13 MCU films.

2. **Market Competition:** The film's release timing may coincide with other major releases in 2024, which could split the audience.

3. **Economic Factors:** Global economic conditions can affect consumer spending on entertainment, potentially impacting box office revenues.

4. **Franchise Fatigue:** There's a possibility, albeit small, that audiences might feel fatigued with superhero films, although strong performances of recent superhero movies suggest this is not yet a significant issue.

Considering these factors, the strong positives outweigh the potential negatives. The unique appeal of the Deadpool-Wolverine team-up, combined with MCU backing and effective marketing, makes it likely that "Deadpool 3" will set a new record for the biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie.

Health and Age: President Biden was born on November 20, 1942, which means he will be 81 years old by July 2024. The White House releases regular health assessments, and as of the latest reports, he is considered fit for duty. 2. Resignation or Removal from Office: There are constitutional processes for removing a president from office (impeachment, resignation, or invocation of the 25th Amendment). Only a handful of presidents have left office early due to assassination, natural death, or resignation. 4. Political Climate: While political tensions exist, there is no current evidence to suggest an imminent threat to President Biden's presidency in terms of legality or governance that would result in him leaving office before the specified date. 5. Unforeseen Events: While it's impossible to predict unforeseen circumstances with absolute certainty (e.g., sudden health issues, unforeseen political events), the probability of such events occurring within the specified timeframe is low. Considering all these factors, it is highly probable that Joe Biden will still be the president of the United States at 11:59 pm on July 31, 2024.

content.text: Resolves YES if Sifan Hassan wins any medal at the 2024 Paris Olympics, NO otherwise

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Sifan Hassan is one of the most accomplished middle and long-distance runners in the world. At the 2020 Tokyo Olympics (held in 2021 due to the pandemic), she achieved an extraordinary feat by winning gold medals in both the 5,000 meters and 10,000 meters, and a bronze medal in the 1,500 meters. This performance demonstrated her exceptional versatility and endurance across multiple events.

In 2023, Hassan made a remarkable debut in the marathon by winning the London Marathon, showcasing her continued excellence and ability to compete at the highest levels in different disciplines. Her success in both track and road racing indicates that she remains at the peak of her athletic performance.

By the time of the 2024 Paris Olympics, Hassan will be 31 years old. Distance runners often maintain their competitive edge into their early to mid-30s, so age is unlikely to be a significant detriment. However, there are factors that could impact her chances:

1. **Competition**: The fields in the middle and long-distance events are highly competitive. Athletes like Faith Kipyegon, Gudaf Tsegay, and Letesenbet Gidey are strong contenders who have produced world-record performances recently.

2. **Injury Risk**: As with any elite athlete, there is always a risk of injury that could affect her training or prevent her from competing.

3. **Event Selection**: It's uncertain which events Hassan will choose to focus on. Competing in multiple events can be physically demanding and might affect her performance.

4. **Performance Fluctuations**: Athletic performance can vary due to factors like form, fitness level, and psychological factors.

Considering her track record, current form, and experience, Hassan has a strong probability of winning at least one medal at the Paris Olympics. While acknowledging the uncertainties, the odds are in her favor given her past Olympic success and continued excellence in international competitions.

question.body:
More information: https://darrellowens.substack.com/p/the-big-zoning-battle-of-berkeley

Must be at the July 23 meeting, resolves YES even if they pass it after midnight (on July 24), resolves YES if they water down the ordinance before passing, resolves NO if they continue the vote to a future meeting, or vote NO on the proposed ordinance.

content.text: Must be at the July 23 meeting, resolves YES even if they pass it after midnight (on July 24), resolves YES if they water down the ordinance before passing, resolves NO if they continue the vote to a future meeting, or vote NO on the proposed ordinance.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the Berkeley City Council has been actively discussing zoning reforms to address the housing affordability crisis in the Bay Area. The 'Missing Middle' ordinance refers to a set of zoning changes aimed at allowing more diverse housing types—such as duplexes, triplexes, and fourplexes—in areas previously restricted to single-family homes. This initiative seeks to increase housing supply and affordability by encouraging the development of medium-density housing.

The political climate in Berkeley is progressive, with a strong focus on social justice and addressing inequality, including housing affordability. There is significant support for increasing housing density among certain council members, housing advocates, and segments of the community concerned about displacement and high housing costs.

However, zoning changes, especially those altering neighborhood character, often face substantial opposition from community members worried about increased density, traffic, parking, and the preservation of historical neighborhoods. Public hearings on such ordinances can be lengthy, and strong opposition can lead to delays, amendments, or tabling of proposals.

Considering the specifics of the resolution criteria:

- Resolves YES if the ordinance is passed at the July 23 meeting (even if watered down or after midnight on July 24).
- Resolves NO if the vote is continued to a future meeting or if the ordinance is voted down.

Given the contentious nature of zoning reforms, there is a significant possibility that the council may not reach a consensus by the July 23 meeting. Procedural delays, extended public comment periods, or strategic postponements are common in local government when dealing with divisive issues.

Based on the progressive push for housing reforms balanced against potential opposition and procedural delays, I estimate the probability that the Berkeley City Council will pass the Missing Middle ordinance at its July 23 meeting to be 40%.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.
